story: Created with Sketch.Join us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsEuropean Parliament's Brexit chief rejects calls for extension of talksClick to followIndy PoliticsThe European Parliament’s Brexit chief has warned Theresa May that the EU will not abandon its principles to “rescue” her party from a looming&nbspdisaster of its own making.Speaking to MEPs on Tuesday Guy Verhofstadt rejected Boris Johnson’s suggestion that talks should be extended, arguing that “enough mess has been created” by Brexit already.“Let’s stop it,” he said, branding the actions of some Tories in recent weeks “insane”.Claims of Tory turf war amid 'shambolic' release of migration planMr Verhofstadt also rejected Sajid Javid’s proposals on immigration controls after Brexit, warning that&nbsp “will never accept discrimination based on skills and nationality, as Mr Javid this morning proposed”.He also criticised the Conservative party for being unable to come up with a common position on “the mess of Brexit” years after it had called the referendum.“We will never undermine the principles of the European project to rescue a political party who is not even capable to find a common line on the mess of Brexit,” he finally told MEPs.Lampooning a string of senior Conservatives, he said: “When you see these insane notions of some Tory politicians of the last days: Boris Johnson, his latest invention, you have seen that? He will solve the problem by building a bridge between the UK mainland and Ireland. Mr Boris Johnson is more known for burning bridges than for building bridges!We will never undermine the principles of the European project to rescue a political party who is not even capable to find a common line on the mess of Brexit“Then there’s Mr Rees-Mogg who’s saying ‘yeah, I have the proposals for the future of Brexit, ordinary citizens and their savings can be secure after Brexit!’ and in the meantime he’s opening for himself an investment fund in Ireland, to transfer his money to Ireland.”He added: “Jeremy Hunt, who is comparing the European Union with the Soviet Union. But in his case that is not so abnormal: he has once even confused Japan with China. This is not the first time this is happening.&nbsp“The previous time he was insulting his wife, but this time it’s something far more different: he’s insulting not us, but millions of ordinary citizens who have lived under Soviet rule for so long. That is in fact a point on which he has to apologise, I think, because we cannot take it as such a thing he said.”Other senior Brussels politicians also used the debate to tear into senior Conservatives. Manfred Weber, leader of the centre-right European People’s Party and an ally of Angela Merkel, told MEPs that British politicians would have to start taking responsibility for their mistakes.“Brexit means leaving the European Union and this means losing the advantages of this Union. BrexitClick to followIndy PoliticsA “significant” number of Tory MPs&nbspwould be prepared to back a second&nbspreferendum on Theresa May’s&nbspBrexit deal, a senior Conservative has said.Ex-attorney general Dominic Grieve said the prime minister was facing a “polite rebellion” of pro-EU Tories&nbspwho think a new vote is “indispensable” to avoiding a damaging no-deal Brexit.Mr Grieve became one of the first senior Tories to break cover over&nbspthe need for a new referendum earlier this year, telling The Independent it was the “only sensible way forward”.Allen backs fresh Brexit referendum saying there is ‘no alternative’He has been&nbspjoined by prominent backbenchers Anna Soubry, Justine Greening, Sarah Wollaston, Philip Lee&nbspand&nbspGuto Bebb – and South Cambridgeshire MP Heidi Allen, who declared the Chequers plan was “dead” on Saturday.The Independent has been campaigning for the public to have a say on any deal Ms May secures with Brussels, which has won the backing of more than 820,000 people.Mr Grieve’s intervention comes at the start of what promises to be a fraught party conference for the prime minister, as she seeks to sell her Brexit plan to her ided party.Labour members voted to keep&nbspthe option of a second referendum&nbsp– including the potential to remain in the EU&nbsp– on the table at their conference last week, which means there could be a&nbspparliamentary majority in favour of another vote, Mr&nbspGrieve&nbspsaid.New Brexit referendum is ‘sensible way forward’, says Dominic GrieveGrieve warns of ‘state of emergency’ if no Brexit deal by FebruaryFinal Say: Rod Stewart backs calls for second referendum on BrexitCorbyn indicates shift in Brexit stance towards final say voteWriting in the Sunday , the MP for Beaconsfield said: “I believe the time has come for a polite rebellion by pragmatic Conservatives.“Including myself, it is now clear that there is a significant group of Conservative MPs who think that a People’s Vote – a vote on the final form Brexit will take, is absolutely indispensable for the future wellbeing of our country.”Mr Grieve&nbspadded: “A no-deal Brexit is a proposal so damaging to our future that it cannot be accepted.“So the only possible response must be to return to the British electorate and ask them what they want. It was the Soviet Union that stopped people leaving.&nbspMay to seek cabinet backing for Brexit proposal changesTheresa May has more support than ever at this Tory conferenceEveryone at the Tory conference knows that May's plan has failedHammond vows MPs will see analysis of no-deal Brexit before votesRestaurant and bar bosses to be banned from snatching workers’ tips“The lesson from history is clear: if you turn the EU club into a prison, the desire to get out won’t diminish, it will grow – and we won’t be the only prisoner that will want to escape.”Pressed on the remarks on BBC1's Breakfast, Ms May replied: As I sit around that table in the EU, there are countries who used to be part of the Soviet Union.&nbspThey are now democratic countries and I can tell you that the two organisations are not the same.&nbspHunt likens EU to Soviet Russia and vows to 'fight' for BrexitAccording to The Times, the incendiary&nbsprhetoric has led to cabinet colleagues of the foreign secretary accusing him of being on leadership manoeuvres &nbspLord Ricketts, the former head of the diplomatic service, added that the comments were unworthy of a British foreign secretary. The EU isn't a Soviet-style prison, he said.&nbspIts legal order has brought peace and prosperity after a century of war. Our decision to leave was always going to leave us worse off. title: Brexit latest news Remain Peoples Vote second referendum Daniel Hannan
story: Speaking at the annual Conservative conference, Mr Hannan said Remainers have a pretty clear plan to thwart Britain's exit from the EU.The Eurosceptic MEP also mocked pro-EU activists who were protesting near the conference hall wearing blue berets.He told a BrexitCentral fringe event in Birmingham: Look at some of the people shouting outside this conference with their curious berets.This is classic cultist behaviour. It's is easy to mock. But my friends, cults are dangerous things, potentially.                Rees-Mogg sounds warning at TOTALITARIAN-ESQUE Brexit block                Rees-Mogg's FURY: Brexiteer MP hits out at Theresa May's Chequers planThe Bolshevists were a cult before 1917, the Iranian ayatollahs were a cult before the overthrow of the Shah.Cults are capable of doing immense damage, and it's now pretty clear what the plan of Remain is.First, they intend to encourage the European Union to say 'no' to any mutually advantageous deal.Then they intend to get a majority in Parliament to vote down whatever comes back.Brexiteer Tory MEP Daniel Hannan branded Remain a &lsquocult&rsquo (Image: EMPICS&bull)The Labour Party has already said they will vote against any deal, and they think they will find enough allies in the other parties.Then they'll try to use that majority to suspend Article 50 and then they'll vote for a second referendum.I'm not saying that any of this is certain, but for heaven's sake, don't assume that we can sit back and take victory for granted.Speaking at the same event, MP Jacob Rees-Mogg claimed the campaign for a second referendum was bordering on totalitarianism.                Brexit: Pressure grows on May as ex-minister hits out at Chequers                EU is the new Soviet Union! Jeremy Hunt in ASTONISHING attack Mr Hannan mocked Remainers for wearing 'curious berets' (Image: )The Brexit campaigner said: We should think carefully about the People's Vote. To my mind, it conjures up totalitarianism.All the countries that are least interested in their people called themselves 'People's'.The People's Republic of China &ndash that's communist. Once you put 'People's' in the title, you know that it's not true.It's not about the people. It's about the elite, it's about the rulers, it's about those who think they should be in charge.

title: brexit news jacob rees mogg conservative party conference leave means leave
story: At a packed Leave Means Leave rally, an EU flag pyjama-wearing protester blasted out music from a portable sound system outside the event room.The music was by &ldquoEU Supergirl, a pro-EU campaigner and singer, and it was played at a volume which brought the event to a halt.But rather than be put off by the protest, Jacob Rees-Mogg responded with trademark good humour.As music blared in from outside, he quipped: &ldquoAnything they can do we can do louder!                Jacob-Rees Mogg responds to Boris Johnson Tory leadership claimsLeave Means Leave co-chair Richard Tice also helped to diffuse the situation.A video has emerged which shows Mr Tice speaking politely to the protestor, who he asked to turn the music off.Remarkably, the protester does so and even apologises before walking away.Political journalist and commentator Isabel Oakeshott said on Twitter: &ldquoThe Leave Means Leave fringe descends into farce as saboteurs attempt to drown out Jacob Rees Mogg with deafening Muzak.Jacob Rees-Mogg responded with trademark good humour (Image: )Mr Rees-Mogg received a standing ovation (Image: )                Brexit news: Juncker says EU will block UK plane landings in no deal                Brexit latest: What is May's concession on Northern Ireland?She later added added: &ldquoRemoaners fail to drown out Jacob Rees-Mogg who is now descanting on Aesop Fables.&ldquoIt&rsquos all become a bit surreal.Mr Rees-Mogg received a standing ovation after his speech at the fringe event.Other speakers included Wetherspoons chief Tim Martin.Leave Means Leave co-chair Richard Tice also helped to diffuse the situation (Image: )Mr Martin said: &ldquoEverything you buy from the EU you can buy from elsewhere in the world - the power lies with the consumer.There were cries of &ldquosack the woman! from hecklers at the event who want Mr Rees-Mogg to support a bid to oust Theresa May.The leading Brexiteer replied: &ldquoAbsolutely not.He claimed that changing the Conservatives leader would cause more problems than it solves and the party should back the Prime Minister.Mr Rees-Mogg is considered a possible successor to May.He said the Conservatives lack of a parliamentary majority meant it would be difficult for an alternative leader to push through an ambitious Brexit deal.

title: brexit news theresa may EU second referendum philippe lamberts
story: The Greens co-leader said the UK should not blame Brussels for a &ldquolack of flexibility over its Brexit stance.Mr Lamberts was addressing MEPs as the Conservative Party conference takes place in Birmingham.He also took a swipe at British foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt after he compared the EU to the Soviet Union.There were intractable contradictions at the heart of Britain's Brexit stance, according to the Eurpoean Parliament MEP.&nbsp                Migrants must adopt British values in immigration shake-upMEP Philippe Lamberts says UK can only be global power in the EU (Image: European Parliament )Mr Lamberts said: The UK decided freely to join the EU, it also decided freely to hold a referendum.To those especially the UK who blame the EU27 for lack of flexibility.We cannot be held responsible for resolving intractable contradictions of the UK.He added: There may come a day in the near future when...the only way for Britain to be global is to be part of the EU.&nbspOur door will remain open to you. You will be always be welcome where the UK really belongs.&nbsp&nbsp                Brexit news: Verhofstadt refuses to sacrifice EU to save the Tories                Theresa May promises to SLASH net migration and end free movementHe accused Mr Hunt of adopting far right rhetoric after comparing the EU27 to the old Soviet Union.The single bloc was united in its Brexit stance, he added, although there had been blunt statements issued during negotiations between London and Brussels, Mr Lamberts said.He said: But they came nowhere close to what we heard from the British foreign secretary who took the now commonplace rhetoric of the rar right comparing the European Union with the Soviet Union.Mr Lamberts warned against the dangers of a no-deal Brexit which would poison relations between Britan and the EU..Both parties should focus on withdrawal negotiations to provide a platform for future relations.MEP Philippe Lamberts takes aim at Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt over Soviet Union comparison (Image: Getty)Mr Hunt's comments were slammed by other MEPs during the parliamentary session.German MEP Manfred Weber blasted the British Foreign Secretary for reaching a new level of populism.Mr Weber said: After March 2019 for the first time Brexiteers will have to take responsibility for their decisions, explain to the people what they did.They won't be able to blame Brussels anymore.

title: kate middleton return royal duties maternity leave prince louis
story: She will be visiting Sayers Croft Forest School and the Wildlife Garden at Paddington Recreation Ground to see how they are helping children&rsquos emotional and physical wellbeing.The Duchess will join in with sessions and hear from instructors at the outdoor learning centre about the beneficial effects of their work.Kate will then make an appearance at a charity event for World Mental Health Day next week, as well as the wedding of Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank in Windsor days later.Although today will mark her first official Royal duty since she went on maternity leave, she has appeared at a few events over the past few months.                When does Kate, Duchess of Cambridge finish her maternity leave?                Kate and William teach children to do this when travellingShe attended the RAF centenary, the Trooping of the Colour, Wimbledon and of course Prince Harry&rsquos wedding to actress Meghan Markle.However, this will be her first solo engagement since the birth of her youngest.Her schedule is looking busier than it was when she returned to royal duties after having Louis&rsquos older siblings - Prince George, 5, and Princess Charlotte, 3.When George was born, Kate was not seen for around six weeks, while with Charlotte she was off for around two months.The Duchess of Cambridge is back at work (Image: )The Royal family at Prince Louis' christening (Image: )This stint of maternity leave has been significantly longer than those that came before, both of which were less than the usual nine months.However, she has undertaken several engagements during this period, which is a break from tradition.Kate and William are known for their hands-on parenting and the family are currently living in their country home, Anmer Hall in Norfolk.Kate has often expressed joy at spending time with her children, especially doing outdoor activities.                Kate Middleton&rsquos brother is working as a tour guide in Scottish hotel                 Princess Eugenie wedding: What dress will Kate Middleton wear?The Duchess of Cambridge attended Wimbledon in July this year (Image: )The centre the Duchess will visit today gives inner-city children the chance to engage with the natural world.She visited a primary school in south-west London last November to see its gardening projects and told pupils she has fond memories of being outdoors as a child.The Duchess said she wishes to pass on that passion to her on children.Kensington Palace announced Kate's return last week.

title: Meghan Markle news Prince Harry Royal wedding chef michelin star
story: Clare Smyth, who cooked at Prince Harry and the Duchess of Sussex's wedding reception, achieved two Michelin Stars - the highest recognition in the world of fine dining.Ms Smyth previously became the first woman to run a three-starred restaurant when she ran Restaurant Gordon Ramsey.On Monday, the Royal chef said she was &ldquodelighted by the announcement and was &ldquoso proud of my amazing team.Ms Smyth told the : &ldquoIt&rsquos nice to be out there and doing it for female chefs.                Royal Wedding: Eugenie to follow in THESE royal footsteps                Royal plea: Meghan Markle's sister in DESPERATE bid to see Duchess &ldquoWe just need to encourage more women to come into the industry and if I can help inspire other people to do that, I think it makes our whole industry better.Commenting on the news, her former boss Gordon Ramsey said: &ldquoShe&rsquos tremendous &ndash she&rsquos the Margaret Thatcher of cooking.&ldquoShe knows what she wants and she comes from a good stable.&ldquoTo get two stars straight away &ndash there are chefs who have been cooking for 30 years and haven&rsquot got two stars &ndash is a testament to her capabilities.The Royal Wedding chef has achieved the most prestigious accolade in the cookery industry (Image: )Ms Smyth cooked for a star-studded guest list at the Royal Wedding (Image: )Ms Smyth said she wanted to welcome more women into a traditionally male-dominated world.Commenting on the fact only one female head chef was honoured at the Michelin Star award ceremony, she said: &ldquoIt&rsquos probably a reflection of the number of women in the industry.&ldquoWe need more women to come into the industry.The award-winning chef catered for 200 people at the Royal Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle on May 19.                Princess Eugenie royal wedding: Queen set to wear THIS colour                Kate returns to Royal duties TODAY five months after giving birthGordon Ramsey said Ms Smyth was the 'Margret Thatcher' of cooking (Image: )For the reception, she cooked &ldquoposh burgers for star-studded guests including George Clooney, the Beckhams, Elton John, and Serena Williams.The private wedding reception took place at Frogmore House, Windsor.Ms Smyth was also awarded an MBE in 2013 for services to the hospitality industry.Prince Harry with his mother-in-law, Doria Ragland  (Image: )She has cooked at some of the most prestigious restaurants in the country - including Heston Blumenthal's The Fat Duck and The Waterside Inn in Bray, Berkshire.The double Michelin Star award was in recognition for her Ms Symth&rsquos new venture, Core, which is based in Notting Hill, west London.The area is also home to some of the most well-unowned eateries in the UK - including the tortuously secretive The Ledbury.Meghan and Prince Harry with Meghan's mother, Doria (Image: )Ms Smyth's Core styles itself an elegant and informal fine dining restaurant with an emphasis on natural, sustainable food, sourced from the UK's most dedicated farmers.It is in the same premises as the eponymous restaurant of Prue Leith from The Great British Bake Off.Food critic Fay Maschler described Core as &ldquoexquisite and Tony Turnbull hailed the &ldquoskill and ambition of Ms Smyth&rsquos first solo venture.

title: Prince charles king royal news the queen abdication
story: The Prince of Wales will be the oldest person to be crowned in British history when he eventually succeeds the Queen.At 69-years-old, his advancing years have led to speculation he could abdicate in favour of his son, Prince William, allowing the monarchy to skip a generation.But he is said to be desperate to become King of the United Kingdom and has spent his whole life preparing to take up his duty, as well as his birthright.Speaking on the second part of ITV documentary &lsquoQueen of the World&rsquo, Prince Charles said very few people understand the sense of &ldquoduty unless they are &ldquobrought up with it.                IDS demands UK restrict EU migrant workers benefits to stop flood o...The 69-year-old said it is his responsibility to &ldquomind about other people, &ldquomind about what happens in this country and the Commonwealth.Reflecting on his role, he said: &ldquoPeople don't always understand about the concept of duty. I think a lot of the time you have to be brought up to understand what it actually means.&ldquoMinding about other people, minding about what happens in this country and the Commonwealth, and that's the only way, all the masses of people who need to be encouraged and thanked.During Prince Charles&rsquo visit to New Delhi, he was meant to meet the children at their school but the poor air quality in the city meant they had to change their venue last minute.Prince Charles has opened up about his duty as a member of the Royal Family  (Image: )Prince Charles was born to be king  (Image:  )Prince Charles joked he would build a fort when he becomes king  (Image:  )The children were instead driven to the British Council instead, as organised by Charles.The heir to the throne joked he would build a fort when he takes to the throne to giggling schoolchildren during a visit to a New Delhi school.Pupil Pragya, nine, asked him: &ldquoWhen you become king, will you build a fort?, to which a laughing Prince Charles exclaimed: &ldquoI will! before clarifying he has no serious plans to build a fort.It was filmed as part of a two-part ITV documentary Queen of the World, which explores the longest-reigning monarch&rsquos role as head of the Commonwealth.

story: Mr Seely made the extreme remarks during an interview with on BBC Newsnight.He told presenter John Sweeney: &ldquoIf we let Jeremy Corbyn into Number 10 Downing Street, frankly we deserve to be collectively shot.The Tory backbencher followed up by arguing the Conservative Party needs a new agenda to prevent a Corbyn premiership.Mr Seely said: &ldquoIf we loose sight of the domestic agenda, which I do feel we&rsquore doing at the moment, I think we&rsquore in trouble.                PM Boris Johnson would DELAY Brexit - plan for EU talks revealed                DUP leader gives HUGE boost to Boris Johnson leadership hopes He argued the domestic agenda is being &ldquosimply drowned out by Brexit and by the leadership shenanigans.He described keeping Mr Corbyn out of power as &ldquomore important than Boris Johnson, more important than Brexit.Mr Seely is MP for the Isle of Wight and was first elected last year.Before that he served in the army reserves and was deployed to both Afghanistan and Iraq.&ldquoIf we let Jeremy Corbyn into Number 10 Downing Street we deserve to be collectively shot (Image:  )&ldquoIf we loose sight of the domestic agenda I think we&rsquore in trouble (Image:  )Mr Seely also used his Newsnight appearance to comment on Mr Johnson&rsquos leadership aspirations.He said: &ldquoI&rsquom not anti-Boris.&ldquoBut when he was Foreign Secretary he didn&rsquot do a great job it has to be said.&ldquoI wouldn&rsquot necessarily vote against him and it might be that our party membership still like him.&ldquoI think he has to prove himself over again.                NO-DEAL BREXIT READY: UK plans HUGE tax cuts to TURBO-CHARGE economy                NO DEAL BREXIT EXPLAINED: What does no-deal Brexit mean for students?He described keeping Mr Corbyn out of power as &ldquomore important than Boris Johnson (Image:  )However, Mr Seely also had harsh words for Prime Minister Theresa May.He asserted: &ldquoShe&rsquos had to struggle.&ldquoShe has made some mistakes and we were too slow in beginning to negotiate seriously over our future with the European Union.&ldquoThese things have cost us.

title: Brexit news Dominic Raab Emmanuel Macron EU negotiations French President BBC newsnight
story: Mr Rabb made the comments during an appearance on the BBC&rsquos Newsnight show which aired last night.He argued last month&rsquos Salzburg summit, where the UK Brexit proposals were rejected, was followed by &ldquosome fairly unsavoury political posturing and tactics.Asked who he was referring to by BBC presenter Emily Maitlis Mr Rabb replied: &ldquoWell we all saw what happened with the language that was used by some of the leaders.Ms Maitlis then specifically asked Mr Raab if he was referring to French President Macron.                DUP leader gives HUGE boost to Boris Johnson leadership hopes                 &lsquoIf Corbyn becomes PM we all deserve to be SHOT&rsquo says Tory MP He confirmed her suspicions before adding: &ldquoBut what I&rsquom not going to do is get in for personalised tit for tat.Mr Macron caused controversy in Salzburg when he said Brexit is the &ldquochoice of the British people, a choice pushed by those who predicted easy solutions.&ldquoThey are liars.During the Newsnight interview Mr Rabb also had harsh words for EU negotiators.&ldquoSome fairly unsavoury political posturing and tactics (Image: BBC NEWSNIGHT )&ldquoWell we all saw what happened with the language that was used by some of the leaders (Image:  )He suggested they were deploying &ldquoa political negotiating strategy which seems designed for political purposes of drawing a wedge across the UK, particularly on Northern Ireland.Last December the UK agreed the so-called &lsquoNorthern Ireland backstop with the EU, meaning Northern Ireland will remain aligned to the European Single Market unless a new deal is accused.Some Brexiteers, including former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, are angrily opposing this backstop which they argue infringes on UK sovereignty.Mr Raab warned the EU that unless they compromise there will be a no-deal Brexit.                PM Boris Johnson would DELAY Brexit - plan for EU talks revealed                DUP leader gives HUGE boost to Boris Johnson leadership hopes What I&rsquom not going to do is get in for personalised tit for tat (Image:  )He said: &ldquoThe reality is we&rsquove shown some ambition and pragmatism.&ldquoIt&rsquos not matched on the EU side then actually we won&rsquot get a deal.&ldquoI&rsquom confident we still can but it needs to be a two way negotiation.Mr Raab admitted the UK and EU are still some way off a formal deal.&ldquoThe reality is we&rsquove shown some ambition and pragmatism (Image:  )He asserted: &ldquoOn the two key outstanding issues of this whole negotiation, the Northern Ireland protocol and the economic partnership, we&rsquove still got some way to go.Mr Raab was a prominent Brexit supporter during the 2016 EU membership referendum.He took over as Brexit Secretary after his predecessor, David Davis, resigned in protest at the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers proposals.

title: brexit news latest immigration policy UK EU theresa may prime minister BBC
story: Trump accuses Democrats of 'turning US into VENEZUELA'BBC News Theresa May dodges Dan Walker&rsquos Boris Johnson question&ldquoNow of course we are also working as a Government to ensure that we&rsquore building up the skills of young people here in the UK, but our new immigration policy is crucially going to ensure that free movement ends.&nbsp&ldquoIt will be determined by their contribution to our economy, not where they come from.Home Secretary Sajid Javid is preparing to set out the immigration blueprint in a speech to the Conservative party conference.He told Tory grassroots at a meeting on the fringes on Monday that he wanted an open system which allowed Britain to attract the best talent from across the globe.It comes after the Migration Advisory Committee published a Government-commissioned report last month.The committee said that if immigration is not part of the negotiations with the EU and the UK is deciding its future system in isolation there should be no preference given to citizens from the European Economic Area (EEA).The bloc includes the present 28 EU countries, as well as Iceland, Norway and Lichtenstein.Ministers will publish a white paper setting out details of how the new system will work in the coming weeks ahead of an Immigration Bill next year.Future immigration policy: May announced the new system would prioritise high-skilled workers (Image: BBC)Migration Watch UK vice chairman Alp Mehmet claimed the proposals were not likely to cut net migration.He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: The overall numbers, frankly, are quite likely to go up if, if the Migration Advisory Committee's recommendations are adopted, simply because it's not just about curbing the number of low-skilled people coming here.He added: We want net migration to come down and these proposals are not likely to do that, you are simply going to replace EU (low-skilled) migration with migration from elsewhere in the world. That's taking your foot off the brake and frankly slipping onto the accelerator.There has been two years already when, frankly, business should have been preparing, they haven't done so, and I think now to be relying on overseas labour when they should have been training and preparing for us coming out of the EU, I think, is wrong.Neil Pattison, Director of hospitality recruitment site Caterer, told Express: &ldquoThe proposed introduction of a new skills-based immigration system will vastly impact the hospitality industry.&ldquoAs it stands the industry does not have enough workers to do the jobs currently available in the market.&ldquoWhile more work needs to be done to close the skills gap and ensure that British people have the right pathways into the hospitality industry, restricting workers from overseas is not the solution.&ldquoThe catering and hospitality industries are set to be some of the most affected by Brexit and we have already seen a reduction in applications from the EU. We need to be focusing our efforts on ensuring the longevity of businesses in this sector.

title: Brexit news Nicola Sturgeon Theresa May Chequers EU single market UK latest
story: The Scottish First Minister is set to deliver a speech to the Europa Institute in Edinburgh today, during which she will attack Downing Street and accuse Mrs May of lacking basic common sense.Ms Sturgeon will claim that even though the Prime Minister achieved her &ldquoChequers plan for Brexit, the policy of taking the UK out of the single market will be catastrophic on the economy.She is expected to say: &ldquoThe prime minister&rsquos current position &mdash that we must leave the single market regardless of the consequences &mdash is an act of wilful economic vandalism.&ldquoShe is ploughing on with a strategy that she knows will reduce household incomes and cost people their jobs.                DUP leader gives HUGE boost to Boris Johnson leadership hopes                 &lsquoIf Corbyn becomes PM we all deserve to be SHOT&rsquo says Tory MP &ldquoShe is doing so because she refuses to change her own interpretation of the referendum result, despite the fact that, whatever people voted for, it clearly wasn&rsquot where we are now.The First Minster will also use her speech to stress how Mrs May's failures in Salzburg highlight the need for the UK to remain in the EU single market.She will also claim that by continuing to pursue Chequers, Mrs May is ploughing on with a strategy that she knows will reduce household incomes and cost people their jobs.Ms Surgeon will say: &ldquoIf I had to pick out a glimmer of hope from the fiascos of the last few weeks it would be this: the very fact that the prime minister&rsquos negotiating position has been exposed as untenable, means that membership of the single market and the customs union must now be a stronger political possibility than at any time in the last two years.Nicola Sturgeon will accuse Theresa May's Brexit plan of being an &ldquoact of wilful economic vandalism (Image: Getty)Sturgeon will argue that taking the UK out of the single market will be catastrophic for the economy (Image: Getty)It is time, at this critical hour, for the Prime Minister to finally face up to reality.The truth is she has lost control of her party and is facing mutiny in Birmingham.With so little time left to conclude a Brexit deal, and with so many jobs and livelihoods at stake, this arrogant self-indulgence by the Conservative Party is unforgivable.Ms Sturgeon has always been a vocal critic of the decision to leave the EU, and has indicated her party&rsquos intention to push for another independence referendum after Brexit.                DUP leader gives HUGE boost to Boris Johnson leadership hopes                 &lsquoIf Corbyn becomes PM we all deserve to be SHOT&rsquo says Tory MP Cabinet members laid the foundations for party unity with Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab yesterday  (Image: Getty)Scotland voted by a margin of 62 percent to 38 percent to remain in the European Union in the 2016 referendum.Echoing the Scottish First Minister despite being on the opposite side of the political spectrum, staunch Brexiteer Boris Johnson has also called for an extension period to attempt to break the current impasse with Brussels yesterday.The news came the same day Cabinet members laid the foundations for party unity with Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab giving a rousing speech telling Tories to come together to see Britain thrive.However, Mr Johnson will use a speech at a fringe event at the Tory conference today to also criticise Mrs May's strategy a move which is being seen as a leadership bid in the form of an anti-Chequers rally.

title: Brexit news UK latest update today Manfred Weber Jeremy Hunt Soviet Union European Union
story: The German MEP raged to the Council that after the UK officially left the European bloc in March, key Brexiteers such as Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt would have to &ldquoexplain their mistakes to the British public over their part in the Brexit process.&nbspHe said: &ldquoThey cannot blame Brussels anymore.Mr Weber claimed that Foreign Secretary Jeremy&rsquos Hunt&rsquos inflammatory comments, which compared membership to the European Union to a Soviet prison, displayed a &ldquonew level of populism over Brexit that would bring &ldquoless future to the country.Mr Weber called upon Jeremy Hunt to apologise for the comments which he made during a keynote speech to the Conservative Party Conference on Monday, which Mr Hunt used to tear into the EU for its intransigence over Brexit.Mr Hunt said: What happened to the confidence and ideals of the European dream? title: james forsyth no home comforts to ease the brexit bind
story: In the bars and on the fringe, vigorous argument will rage about what the best Brexit option is for Britain.Cabinet ministers will whisper in corridors about what the Government should do next. Boris Johnson will draw a big crowd for his “Chuck Chequers” rally.But there is a bigger danger waiting in the wings for the Tories: They simply don’t have a domestic agenda big enough for the moment.Labour has, over the past few days, set out its vision for Britain. It is, in places, scary. But give Jeremy Corbyn and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell this, it is undoubtedly clear and bold. As one Cabinet minister says, half admiringly:  “They’re hungry.”The Tories need to show  they have a better plan, one that will deal with people’s concerns— and they don’t have any time to waste. As one minister warns: “I’m just really terried. People don’t realise what a big deal this is.”The Tory Party’s problem is that it isn’t giving the country a vision of where it wants to take it. One former party leader has taken to lamenting that the Tories have “lost the narrative”.At conference last year, Theresa May declared that it was her mission to solve the housing crisis, to restore the British dream of home ownership for the many.But in the past  months, the Government has made far too little progress on this. Yes, some sensible steps have been taken. But the policies that will really solve this crisis, proper planning reform and a massive, Government-led housebuilding programme, haven’t happened.The result of all this: Jeremy Corbyn gets closer to power. As this newspaper revealed yesterday, Labour is now ahead in the seats that decide general elections thanks to its massive lead among renters.The likelihood of someone in their late twenties or early thirties on an average salary owning their own home has halved in the past  years.This is an electoral time bomb for the Tories. They can’t expect those without capital, or any prospect of getting it, to be capitalists.By the time of the next election, the Tories need to show people that their lives are getting better AND explain the damage  Corbyn would do to the country.One minister points the finger of blame at Number  for the Tory predicament. “A fish rots from the head down,” he tells me. But the Cabinet can’t escape its share of the blame, either.With a few exceptions, min­isters aren’t doing enough to take on Labour’s arguments. As one former Secretary of State fumed to me during Labour conference: “It’s outrageous. Where are the Cabinet ”If the Tories get Brexit wrong, it could cost them the next election. But eventhey get a decent deal, it won’t guarantee them victory. For the public will vote on domestic issues — whether the housing crisis is solved, the state of the health service and what is going on with schools.Corbyn has simple answers to all these questions: They might be wrong, but they are answers. The Tories now need to show the country  they have answers too.AT last, some positivity and optimism about this country’s post-Brexit future from the Government.I can reveal  it is planning a major new festival celebrating the UK for . The aim is for this festival to tell the world a story about Britain as we leave the EU and take charge of our own future. It is meant to coincide with the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee and the Commonwealth Games, which will be held in Birmingham that year.Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright,  who is pushing this idea in Whitehall, has told colleagues  it will be: “Future-facing, telling a story about the UK’s unique strengths, particularly as a place to invest, as we forge a new future outside the European Union.”If the Government gets it right, this festival could be a great statement about the open, dynamic country that Britain is going to be after Brexit. It should emphasise how this country is going out into the world after leaving the EU, not pulling up the drawbridge.The aim should be to put on something that stands comparison with the great post-war Festival of Britain in  or even the Great Exhibition of , which showcased Victorian Britain’s global reach and technological edge.One Secretary of State, who is backing the idea, tells me: “People just want something really positive.”But cynics might note that there is an advantage for the Tories in a feel-good festival in an election year.But I understand he will  have a harsh message for the Westminster politicians in attendance. He will  tell them to stop bickering and positioning and get on with delivering for the country.Mr Street will say that outside the Westminster bubble, the public just want politicians to get on with things, rather than constantly jostling for position.What makes his  speech so interesting is that he is a Downing Street favourite. Indeed, I understand  some of those close to Theresa May are pushing for a similar tone in her speech.They believe  her post-Salzburg speech went down so well with the public not just because she was standing up to the EU but because she was taking charge and being that “bloody dficult woman”. They think she should use her speech to tell members  they won’t get everything  they want from the Brexit talks, but that she will get the best deal for Britain.Others, though, are wary of this approach. One Cabinet minister cautions that after last year, May should play it safe as “you can’t have two bad years  in a row”.THE Government has rightly guaranteed that the three million EU citizens living in Britain will be able to stay in the event of no deal.This is sensible. These citizens contribute a lot to this country, and help keep our economy and our public services moving.But it is also right that the Government is now discussing what the rules will be for deporting EU citizens who commit crimes after Brexit in a no-deal scenario.The details have not yet been decided and, as one government source puts it: “No one wants people deported for getting a parking ticket.”But it is right that those who are convicted of a signicant offence are removed.• SPOT the leadership bid will be one of the games  the Tories play in Birmingham.Any Cabinet minister who starts talking about their childhood will be accused of planning a run for the top job.  This leaves ministers walking a tightrope as they prepare their speeches. Some are dealing with this challenge by handing their time  to others.Penny Mordaunt, the Aid Secretary, is simply introducing a series of “British heroes” who do development work.But one of those involved in conference planning suspects that even this is about leadership as Mordaunt “doesn’t want to spend  minutes defending the aid budget to a hall of Tory activists”.James Forsyth is political editor of The Spectator.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Sixteen budding entrepreneurs battling it out to win £k of Lord Sugar’s own money as an investment to start their own business.Alan goes into partnership with the winner — and that’s where Claude Littner and I come in.We are there to make sure he chooses the right person, by watching what happens when the contestants are out on tasks.People know it’s that time of year when they see Claude and I out on the streets with a notepad, pen and film crew.We don’t mentor, we don’t coach or give any guidance, we simply watch what unfolds. And what is amazing to me is how often people try to wriggle out of things and deny a decision they made, in a bid to stay in the process. So when they sit in the boardroom saying, “I didn’t . . . ” we can say, “Oh yes you did . . . ”Some people ask mecertain scenes are staged, but the show is unique in that there are no retakes, there is no setting up of scenes and no trying to find the comedy moment — they just come naturally.All of Alan’s jokes come naturally, too. There is no script, no autocue, it happens as it happens.Luckily, we get on very well — Claude, Alan and I. So much so that we all went on holiday together this year.We’re all quite similar, we have all been married for a long time and we all share the same family values.It makes us a watertight team, although we each bring something dferent to the table.But, parking that for a moment, The Apprentice is also top-notch entertainment — this series more than ever. What’s great about the first episode is that the contestants, all of whom talk the talk about how fantastic they are, are thrown into the deep end with a task that’s designed to test their logic.They are sent on what is a bit like a treasure hunt, in Malta, armed only with a map and some euros.This task is all about logistics, negotiation and identying, and let’s say it doesn’t end well.It turns out that, unfortunately, logic is not something all the contestants are in possession of.During this series we will travel all over the country, including to Glasgow to sell emerging artists’ work to the unsuspecting public.When I say that task was more challenging than ever, I’m referring partly to the challenge of actually getting to Glasgow because it was during the storms. Remember them Turbulence was an under-statement. On the flight there, I was gritting my teeth and grabbing on to Claude like there was no tomorrow.One thing I love about the show is that there are equal numbers of men and women, and they are on a level playing field.Let’s face it, the same cannot be said out there in the “real” world.One thing I’ve been reflecting on over the course of my time on The Apprentice is how much things have changed for women in business since I started out.When I was having my kids  years ago, the very notion of “work-le balance” didn’t exist. But I’m pleased to say that working women aren’t trying to Have It All any more, and the days are gone when women feel the need to keep quiet about having kids at work.Women are now more able to demand flexible working and feel entitled to have time off for, say, ante-natal classes.More “mumpreneurs” are starting their own businesses. Still, you rarely catch working mothers using childcare as a reason for being absent from work — while men, I’ve noticed, almost get points for doing so.And it is still the case that working mothers and women working flexibly are less likely to be promoted.So I don’t quite agree with Ann Widdecombe, the former Tory MP, who wrote this week that women today have “never had it so good” yet still “whinge” about inequality.Because while it might be true that things have changed for the better, most CEOs are still male.Women might never have had it so good but it’s still not good enough — and it’s not “whingeing” to point that out.HONESTLY, watching Jeremy Corbyn forgetting Labour’s six tests for a Brexit deal, when interviewed by the BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg, was like watching a hapless buffoon.No wonder he got two Es at A-level.This is the leader of the party that makes it up as it goes along – buying votes, promising everyone everything . . . and delivering absoutely nothing.As Margaret Thatcher said, The problem with socialism is that you eventually run out of other people’s money.HERE, The Apprentice star Karren picks out some highlights to look forward to during the show’s new season . . .Wyatt said: “Bill Cosby is doing great . . . Mr Cosby knows that God is watching over him . . . he knows that these are lies.“They persecuted Jesus and look what happened . . .  I’m not saying Mr Cosby is Jesus, but we know what this country has done to black men for centuries.”Just to be clear, Cosby’s conviction has nothing to do with race.The man is accused of rape and drug-facilitated sexual assault, by an astonishing  women . . . of all races and ages including some as young as .He has finally been put in prison and his victims have justice. He is a vile rapist, a violent sexual predator.His sentence is based on his crimes, not his colour.Unlike Cosby – a “disgusting sexual deviant” according to one of his victims – Jesus was innocent of the crimes laid against him.Cosby, meanwhile, has admitted to giving sedatives to young women in order to have sex with them.In short, Cosby admits his crimes, the jury find him guilty and the judge sentences him.Attempts to make this out as a racial issue are simply ridiculous.I KNOW it’s hard for men to face up to losing their hair, but someone needs to tell David Beckham that by far the best approach when it happens is . . . acceptance.But, judging from the photos of him looking a bit like a smiling Brillo pad this week that is not the route he is taking.David,you are reading this, you are a handsome man and no one caresyou have a thick head of hair or not – please don’t turn into Shane Warne.I guess the reality star has yet to realise no one is forcing her to go out.She just needs to learn the power of saying no.In the past, I had a dreadful habit of saying yes to an engagement when I meant no, then spent days trying to think of ways to get out of it.I completely changed my le when I decided to simply things by saying yes to an invitation when I wanted to go – and no when I didn’t.IT’S hard to believe not only that West Midlands Police are allowing “thrill-seekers” to spend Halloween in a cell used by serial murderer Fred West – but that they are charging them £ to do so.Offering this “spooky ghost hunt” at the notorious Steelhouse Lane cells in Birmingham is in very poor taste – so disrespectful of West’s victims, including his daughter who is a surviving casualty of his and is clearly still suffering every day.No doubt the relatives of those West murdered still suffer every day, too.So the fact that a stay in his old prison cell is being offered as Halloween entertainment is positively ghoulish.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brave brexit vote
story: In the largest vote ever recorded in Britain, we chose to leave the Brussels racket.And as she reveals in our exclusive interview, Theresa May is determined to tell the world that we are getting out, no s, no buts.Tory Conference this week will be testy. There remain serious splits in the party over Brexit but on one thing they must be united: nothing can imperil our exit.But while the PM is right that a second referendum is for the birds, the country is constantly holding a referendum on her leadership.On domestic issues it is Labour that seems to have an answer to everything — eventhose easy solutions rely on made-up money and would be disastrous in practice.Governments cannot just promise the world in airy-fairy speeches but, faced with an Opposition full of empty promises, the Tories must be radical.They cannot just deliver watered-down versions of whatever Jeremy Corbyn has cooked up.There are plenty of brains in the Tory party. Let’s hear their ideas and a real vision of what Britain can be.IT is disgraceful that major food stores are exploiting a legal loophole to avoid showing ingredients on packaging.Teenager Natasha Ednan-Laperouse’s death should serve as a warning of how dangerous this practice is.The law states that when food is prepared onsite, ingredients labelling is not necessary. It is designed to protect small, independent stores.But our investigation today reveals large chains have not learnt from this avoidable tragedy.Pret a Manger was warned nine times about the dangers of sesame seed in its artisan baguettes and yet it continues to sell items without allergy warnings.Now Natasha’s mother Tanya has challenged the chain to lobby for a change in our labelling laws.And, hopefully, stop other parents having to suffer such a terrible loss.BON appétit, M’luds. You’re scoffing and quaffing grub and booze to the tune of £, A DAY and WE’RE footing the bill.The House of Lords, which is filled with political cronies and gloried lobbyists,represents the very worst of Whitehall’s snouts-in-the-trough culture.The sooner we have an elected House with a few handpicked specialists, the better.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may conference speech cough
story: As the Tory conference kicks off today, the PM has caught a touch of the snfles.She is now desperately fighting to get back to good health so that her big speech on Wednesday isn’t ruined like it was last year.Mrs May couldn’t stop coughing during her keynote address at the  conference, which was also overshadowed by a prankster brandishing a fake P and letters falling off the backdrop behind her.She admitted to The Sun on Sunday that she’s been feeling unwell since ing from a trip to New York last week.The PM said: “I’m not sure it is actually coming out as a proper cold.“I’ve been over to the States and I think on the long flight you get a bit sort of... you know.”She added that party chiefs have fine-tuned her schedule to ensure she’s not tired out by appearing at too many events with activists.Speaking to the BBC’s Sunday Politics this morning, Mrs May said: “The problem for the leader is that they always speak at the end of the conference, whereas everybody  is able to do theirs beforehand.”She then started coughing - and quipped: “You’ve put the jinx on me!”And in a Sunday Times interview, Mrs May joked that she will take a “sackful” of cough sweets on stage with her for the speech.At last year’s event, Philip Hammond ended up handing her a pack of lozenges as she struggled on stage.Tory chairman Brandon Lewis suggested the party had taken efforts to secure the stage this year so that it doesnt start falling apart again.He told the BBC: We are checking the stage and making sure its a good stage for people to be able to view, enjoy and have a really good conference while they are in the hall.Mrs May is hoping to use the party gathering in Birmingham to see off threats to her leadership from the likes of Boris Johnson.

title: theresa may chequers brexit conservative conference boris johsnon
story: As the Tory conference started in Birmingham yesterday, the PM gave angry delegates hope by hinting there was “flexibility”.Meanwhile, Tories on all sides of the Brexit debate rallied round her after Boris Johnson launched his most personal attack yet.Marking the start of the Tories’ choppy annual conference in Birmingham, the under fire party leader told BBC’s Andrew Marr Show that a free trade deal is “at the heart of Chequers”.She also refused to rule out further fudges with the EU despite being asked to five separate times.And behind closed doors, Mrs May gave angry Tory delegates hope by saying there will be “flexibility” with Chequers in the last few weeks of negotiations.During a National Convention meeting with regional party bosses, The Sun has learned that the PM also conceded for the first time that her full plan to keep to the EU’s rules on goods and collect its customs tarfs has been knocked back by EU bosses.But “aspects of it will still work”, Mrs May told them.The key concessions came as senior Tories on all sides of the Brexit ide lashed out at Boris after the former Foreign Secretary issued his most personal attack on the PM yet.The mop haired senior Tory branded her Chequers plan for a softer Brexit “deranged”, and questioned whether she really believes in exiting the EU at all.That left Mrs May being forced to insist: I do believe in Brexit.But a long list of senior party figures seized on Boris’s latest diatribe in a Sunday newspaper to accuse him of attention seeking,Former Brexit Secretary and fellow Leave campaigner David Davis attacked Boris for coming up with “good headlines not good policies”.Scots Tory leader Ruth Davidson accused Boris of hypocrisy, branding it “strange” he is attacking Mrs May’s Northern Ireland backstop pledge having previously heaped praise on her for it when he was in the Cabinet.And in the more caustic comments of all, and TV celebrity Lord Digby Jones leaped on Boris for saying f*** business’.The former business minister told the party faithful from the conference patfrom: It showed him up to be the irrelevant and offensive person he really is.The Sun can also reveal a group of Tory MPs who have formed an ‘Anyone But Boris’ campaign to frustrate any leadership bid intend to boo Mr Johnson at a conference rally he will headline on Tuesday.One Tory minister said: “Several colleagues have said they are going to give Boris a taste of their own medicine and turn up to boo him.“He won’t be very happy at the idea that some of us are getting very fed up with his antics.”The backlash came as three dferent polls also yesterday revealed Mrs May is still liked by more voters than Boris.If the election was a two way race, a BMG Research poll for HuffPost UK found % backed Jeremy Corbyn versus % who supported Boris.But in answer to the same question comparing Mrs May and Mr Corbyn, the PM came out on top by % to %.Meanwhile, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt warned Brussels would stir Britain’s “Dunkirk spirit”it forced a bad deal on Mrs May.He told The : “If President Macron thinks we will come crawling back to the club in a few years’ time, it is a profound misreading of our character.”In what was seen as the first of a series of pitches at the four day conference to succeed Mrs May, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt compared the EU to the Soviet Union yesterday for treating Britain as a prisoner it won’t allow to leave.Remainer-turned-Brexiteer Mr Hunt told the hall: “What happened to the confidence and ideals of the European dream  The EU was set up to protect freedom.“It was the Soviet Union that stopped people leaving.Mr Hunt also issued a plea for warring Tory factions to come together and end their Brexit civil war.He added: “We can only unite the countrywe are united ourselves. In Parliament. In the Government. And in the Cabinet”.Meanwhile hardline backbench Tory Brexiteers put on a concerted show of strength last night hinting they could oust the PMshe did not change her Chequers plan.Boris’s close ally Conor Burns took direct aim, warning: I say to the Prime Minister - we dont want to change you, we want you to change the policy of Chequers.And he urged her to please, please adopt a Canada style trade deal instead, suggesting the affection he held for the PM was at breaking point.And he was backed at the Brexit Central website rally by Jacob Rees Mogg, who said Chequers was “not only a dying duck in a thunderstorm, it’s the deadest dying duck in a thunderstorm.And he blasted campaigners for a so-called Peoples Vote, comparing them to Chinese communist and Libyan tyrant Gaddafi.He said: Once you put peoples in the title it is not true, it is about the elite, about those in charge and we should be very careful about that.A former Defence Minister also accused the PM of behaving like scheming Italian prince Machivelli and risked sending betrayed Tory voters into a political wilderness.Mark Francois - who served as Conservative frontbencher for  years - told The Sun the Chequers plan looks like “some Machiavellian process or series of backstairs deals” that has “sought to overturn their clearly expressed decision”.And he said the political weather meant those Brexit-loving Tory voters would be left homeless and may never vote again.A study yesterday revealed that Brexit is already costing the public purse £m a week.The Centre for European Reform’s analysis found the UK economy is already .% smaller than it would have been had Remain won the referendum.But in an attempt at a Brexit boost, ministers announced that the UK will host a nationwide Festival of Britain  Northern Ireland in .FORMER Labour Minister Digby Jones warned pro-business Tories must unite as “Jeremy Corbyn is to wealth creation what Diane Abbott is to mathematics”.SCOTS Tory MP Ross Thomson savaged the one word conference slogan “OPPORTUNITY”, raging: “I couldn’t help thinking of the other words ‘missed’, ‘lost’, ‘wasted’ and ‘squandered’.”TRANSPORT boss Chris Grayling’s own train to Birmingham was late — but he was spotted passing the time playing FarmVille on his phone rather than working.FORMER Remainer Jeremy Hunt delighted the Leave-backing party faithful by comparing the EU to the Soviet Union and then channelling Maggie Thatcher by telling Brussels “no, no, no”.TORY Peter Bone said ex-Ukip boss Nigel Farage should be made a Lord and put in charge of Brexit, adding: “If he had been in charge, we would have been out by now.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond brexit speech trevor kavanagh opinion
story: He is also writing his ­Halloween Budget on October . Nobody is hoping for voter-friendly treats.For a man in charge of our economic destiny at such a momentous time, this “stubby-pencilled accountant” has precious little to say. It seems he even remained mute at a recent Cabinet session to war-game a No-Deal Brexit — surely the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s special subject.Well-informed Spectator editor Fraser Nelson says other ministers piled in with upbeat projects but Hammond “seemed to have no ideas and kept quiet”. Spreadsheet Phil possesses either supreme self-confidence or total contempt for the .million who voted for Brexit, or both.The man who a year ago faced political death has become the most powerful figure in Theresa May’s Cabinet — perhaps including herself.She remains the figurehead. But the minister she planned to axe until her botched General Election is running the Brexit show from his Treasury eyrie.Hammond’s sympathetic image as Eeyore, a woebegone soft toy, is misleading. This man combines thin-skinned arrogance with a rare combination of political disabilities — cloth-eared, ham-fisted and leaden-footed.The grey image of bungled Budgets and barren creativity stands in vivid contrast to his outrageous Project Fear scaremongering. Mrs May certainly deserves blame for her hapless EU negotiations and the mutant Chequers plan for a Hi-HoBrexit.THE Tories have made a decent start to their conference – but they need to set their ambitions higher.Last week the Labour Party promised easy answers on everything from housing to the economy. It was a radical,utterly disastrous, vision for Britain.The Government changing tipping rules and increasing taxes on foreign property buyers is pretty small beer.Not least since the former was first announced three years ago and the latter is pretty much copied from last year’s Labour manesto.Philip Hammond — rarely mistaken for a ray of sunshine — needs to provide light at the end of the austerity tunnel.He must lay the groundwork for entrepreneurs to thrive in a newly liberated, unapologetically free market economy.And he should challenge business to work with him, too. The self-appointed “voices of British business”, iniably dominated by large corporate interests, push every day for more and more Brexit concessions.Yet as last week showed, Labour’s unreconstructed Marxism is a far more serious threat to future prosperity than any kind of Brexit.It’s time for big businesses to play their part in building a better Britain, rather than refighting a referendum which was as much a vote against them as the political establishment.Eeyore Hammond must encourage them to invest in Britain’s future.She survived last year’s election catastrophe only because Remainers feared a true Brexiteer such as Boris Johnson might replace her.Hammond has since deployed his Treasury reach to capitalise on her weakness and box us into BRINO — Brexit In Name Only. Mrs May is the willing captive of passionate Remainers in Downing Street, Whitehall, the Cabinet Office and, crucially, the all-powerful Treasury.Since the departure of close aide Nick Timothy, there is nobody within earshot who voted Brexit — including Mrs May. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, like his predecessor David Davis, has virtually no say in negotiations.Hammond now calls the shots, backed by panic-stirring Business Secretary Greg Clark and Europhile Cabinet Office minister David Lidington.Brexiteers fear this Unholy Trinity is ready for more concessions over issues including migration, EU benefits and Britain’s vital financial services industry.Never forget, it was Hammond who blocked all spending and therefore all serious preparation for No Deal, a prospect now apparently facing this nation. In fact there was never a chance of No Deal.We will end up with a form of Chequers, but one even more pro-Brussels than the proposal which saw David Davis and BoJo storm out. Remainers are back in full Project Fear mode.European car firms are happily pouring billions into Britain — despite Brexit. Yet Greg Clark triggered last week’s chorus of fake alarm from Toyota, claiming its “just-in-time” supply chain would grind to a halt.This ignores the whole point of “just-in-time”. It is designed specically to cope with delivery glitches and operates worldwide in all circumstances under global trade rules.It was also Clark who handed Brussels its biggest anti-Brexit card by promising those shroud-waving car giants the UK would remain under EU rules. That led directly to Mrs May’s surrender over the Northern Ireland border, which has plagued negotiations ever since.It is a tragic fact — but no surprise — that we are now heading remorselessly for a deal on EU terms at our expense.EU leaders were never going to see us thrive outside. They insisted we will not be better off after Brexit.Anyone who hoped we might be set free to compete on equal terms should read ex-Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis’ story of his own country’s punishment beating.It was Varoufakis who compared Brexit with the Eagles’ hit: “It’s like Hotel Calornia — you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.” And we can blame Phil Hammond for blocking the fire Brexits.But Ms Jourova, a Czech raised under Soviet rule, wants Corbyn-style “regulation” of the free Press.The apple never falls far from the tree.PS. I wonder how M Macron feels after Europe’s Ryder Cup triumph in Paris... without a single French golfer And SIX from the UK!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gp surgery worker mum hangs herself after losing job
story: Victoria Pocock, , killed herself while her partner and their infant son were asleep upstairs.The -year-old was found hanging at the bottom of the stairs by her partner, who quickly put their -month-old son back to bed before dialling .The coroner heard that the operator told James Smith to cut his partner down and to start CPR but despite his best efforts and those of paramedics who later arrived, she was declared dead at the scene in Lambourn, near Hungerford, Berkshire.The inquest heard how Miss Pocock had battled depression for a number of years and had recently lost her job at a GP surgery.A statement from Dr Christa Teplickywas read out by Senior Berkshire Coroner Heidi Connor.Dr Teplicky said: Miss Pocock had been employed by a cleaning company that worked at the GP surgery.“The last time she was seen as a patient at the clinic was on March , but she was seen afterwards in the evenings when she was cleaning.Her main complaint was that she struggled to sleep. She was prescribed the anti-depressant Citalopram, as well as Zopiclone, a sleeping medication.When I saw her in December  she reported she was feeling much better and said she was looking forward to Christmas.Miss Pococks partner, Mr Smith, awoke at .am to hear their young son crying from his bedroom.When he had picked up the tot he looked down the stairs to see the boys mother hanging at the bottom of the stairs.The coroner, sitting in Reading, Berkshire, heard that Mr Smith put his son back to bed and called .Detective Constable Stephens went to the scene and also provided a report for Mrs Connor.He said: Mr Smith arrived back home on April  at about : pm and he found Miss Pocock drinking Corona beer.They went to bed and, at approximately :am, Mr Smith woke up and his partner was still asleep next to him.At .am he awoke to his son crying and went to get him up. He then noticed Miss Pococks body at the bottom of the stairs.He put his son back in his room and called . The operator instructed him to cut the cord around Miss Pococks neck and to start CPR.Paramedics attended the scene but she was declared le extinct at :am on April . When I arrived at the scene the deceased was lying on the floor. There were no apparent self-defence marks.Two red-inked letters were found, which were suicide notes. There was sad music playing from the television. It was How to Save a Le by the band The Fray.Miss Pocock also sent a text to her mother at :am, in which she said she was struggling.According to Mrs Connor, the contents of the two red letters set out a clear intention [Miss Pocock] intended to end her le.A toxicology report found that Miss Pocock had  mg of alcohol per  millilitres of blood in her system when she died, which was just over twice the legal limit of mg per ml.Cocaine was also found in her blood stream, as well as a high therapeutic amount of anti-depressant Citalopram.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military honours, to avoid “hurting Pete’s feelings”, floating off into the sunset like a warning to humanity.This MorningSemra Haksever: “I call myself an eclectic witch, so I take dferent little bits of magic from all over the place.So it’s all b******sOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: belgium demands uk security zeebrugge
story: Immigration minister Theo Francken wants the UK to strike a new treaty with his country to tighten up security at the major port of Zeebrugge.In an interview with The Sun he said Britains loose ID controls and booming black market are proving a major pull factor for illegal migrants. Mr Francken met with Home Secretary Sajid Javid in London yesterday to discuss the growing problem.He revealed many failed asylum seekers who have been denied the right to stay in Germany are now living rough in Belgium while they try to get to Britain.In particular smuggling gangs are targeting the countrys biggest cargo port Zeebrugge, which runs major routes to Hull and Teesport.Mr Francken, an immigration hardliner from the nationalist New Flemish Alliance, now wants the UK to offer similar help as it does to Calais.He said: We have a lot of failed asylum seekers trying to go to the UK for the moment. Certainly from Germany, so they arrived in -.Mostly theyre from Iraq and now theyre saying we dont want to , lets try to go to the UK. We hope to have an agreement because were really demanding the UK do more for the border protection of Zeebrugge port.We need a UK-Belgium bilateral as soon as possible because the problem is really increasing and the Brits have to help us out.Mr Francken said the pull factor of Britain was a common problem, not only a Belgian one and was fuelled by our huge black market exploiting migrants.He said: They all want to go to your country because you dont have identity cards, your black market is very lucrative, you have a lot of English speaking migrants already from those communities.Its a real big push factor your country, the British way of le. I like a lot the Brits but now they need to help us and they said they will do that, but we need a concrete arrangement.The Belgian minister, who is championing a tough Australian-style immigration system to secure Europes outer borders, also warned Brexit wont help reduce the flow.He said: They will not stop because youre out of the EU, the EU has nothing to do with this. title: kids that go to nursery do better
story: Researchers say mixing with other youngsters under the supervision of professional carers is best for tots’ psychological development.Previous studies revealed early childcare can also boost a child’s language and thinking skills and make them more intelligent.The findings should ease the guilt experienced by some parents who choose to leave their children with strangers andto work.Boffins from Sorbonne University, in Paris, tracked the emotional development of , children from birth to eight years old.Their parents completed multiple surveys focusing on issues such as dficulties making friends, hyperactivity inattention, conduct, and social skills.They also reported what type of childcare had been provided up to the age of three, such as nursery, friends family or private childminder.Some % of kids had persistently high levels of bad behaviour, % were hyperactive and % had emotional issues.Around % found it dficult to make friends and % had poor social skills.Those who received formal care – such as in a nursery or crèche – performed best and those who had a childminder fared worst.Kids who dont attend nursery find it more dficult to make friendsDr Maria Melchior, from Sorbonne, said nursey kids may receive more mental stimulation from play, praise and reading and be forced to follow rules.She added: “Access to high quality childcare in the first years of le may improve children’s emotional and cognitive development, prevent later emotional dficulties and promote prosocial behaviours.”Future research will examine whether these benefits translate into a lower risk of psychiatric disorders in later le.The findings are published in the Journal of Epidemiology  Community Health.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
