title: plaque-installed-to-mark-home-of-champion-golfer
story: Andrew and Audrey Inglis recently installed a plaque in memory of Willie Park seniorat their house on Ravensheugh Road ndash near Musselburgh Links, one of the oldest golf courses in the world, where the famous Wallyford golfer spent his last days.They found about the historical link from Ian Wood, former sub-postmaster at Levenhall, after he spotted information online about the four-time Open winner.Mr Wood said: ldquoIt made mention that he died at Levenhall.ldquoWhilst I knew a little bit about golf history and its strong links with Musselburgh during my  years, up until , as sub-postmaster there, this was the first mention Irsquod seen of the Willie Park connection to Levenhall as opposed to Musselburgh and the Old Course.ldquoI use the Scotlandrsquos People website run by the National Records of Scotland in my local and family history research so quite quickly found Williersquos death registration in  together with the Park family entry on the  Census: both at Laurel Bank, Levenhall.ldquoI knew the house owners as former customers so when I next saw them I mentioned what Irsquod discovered and expected them to know about it, particularly as Andrew, like me, is a keen golfer. However, this was news to him and his we Audrey so I passed them copies of what Irsquod found.Mr Inglis made contact with Historic Scotland which supported his request to have the plaque installed on the front of their house.And Mr Inglis, who has lived in the house  years, said: ldquoWe are quite proud to tell people about it. It is good to support Musselburghrsquos heritage and do everything you can to attract people to the town.ldquoI have been up to the loft to seethere are any of Willie Park seniorrsquos putters but there are none!In a twist of fate, Mr Woodrsquos daughter and son-in-law live on Park Drive, Wallyford, which was named after Willie Park senior, a four-time winner of The Open.Mr Wood said: ldquoI think the plaque is a fitting tribute to Willie Park senior.He suggested that it would be good to see some kind of golfing trail, with accompanying leaflet, produced for the Honest Toun.A successful golf exhibition, curated by the great-grandson of Willie Park senior, Mungo Park, was held at Musselburgh Museum in the summer. He was in the town again last week to give a talk on Musselburghrsquos importance in the history of the sport.He said: ldquoMusselburgh Museumrsquos exhibition has just restored some of the townrsquos proper reputation in golf history.ldquoI am grateful to the owners of Laurel Bank and to Historic Scotland for giving my great-grandfather a singular place in that history. There are many others in the town whose story is as rich, and I hope that Musselburghrsquos position as the th centuryrsquos lsquohome of golfrsquo will come to be more widely understood.

title: sisters-set-to-raise-four-figure-sum
story: Musselburgh resident Veronica Noone, , took part in the September  event along with her sister Trisha Francis, , from Manchester, in aid of the charity Crohnrsquos  Colitis UK after family members were diagnosed with the conditions.They joined about , runners for the .-mile half marathon which stretched from Newcastle-upon-Tyne to South Shields.The siblings, who are originally from Tyneside, crossed the finishing line in two hours  minutes.Sir Mo Farah sealed a record-breaking fth victory by winning the elite menrsquos race in  minutes and  seconds.Among the celebrities taking part were singer Olly Murs, news presenter Sophie Raworth and model Nell McAndrew.Veronica, who has lived in Musselburgh for  years, and also serves as vice-chairwoman of Fisherrow Harbour and Seafront Association, said: ldquoWe got on great and have so far raised pound, but there is still more coming in.Veronica has also raised pound by offering work colleagues at Scottish Enterprise the chance to repaint parts of a le-size cow model from Cow Parade Edinburgh in exchange for donations.Its paint had been washed off following the event in , but the now repainted brightly coloured cow stays on a balcony at Scottish Enterprisersquos Edinburgh office.A pound contribution was given to Veronicarsquos cause from the staff charity fund.Crohnrsquos disease and ulcerative colitis are the two main forms of inflammatory bowel disease, affecting more than , people in the UK.To donate, go to justgiving fundraising veronica-noone

title: update-emergency-services-called-out-to-astley-house-in-north-berwick
story: Four fire engines attended Astley House, on the towns Dirleton Avenue, shortly after pm this afternoon .Residents at the nursing home were not evacuated, but gathered in the conservatory while fire crews dealt with the smoke, which theCourierunderstands was in a cupboard in a communal area of the nursing home.No-one was hurt but some residents have been transferred to the nearby Fidra Nursing Home.Dirleton Avenueremains closed in both directions and traffic in the surrounding area is much heavier than normal.The first fire crew stood down a short time ago, and police hope to have the road back open soon.

title: folk-favourites-yard-of-ale-ready-for-two-good-causes
story: The trio will raise funds for the Hollies Day Centre for older people and Musselburgh born Tom Fairnie, a singer-songwriter, who is preparing to go the musical trip of a letime to the USA.Yard of Ale was originally formed in  when Ian Lawson, Alistair McDougald and Colin Mackenzie all found themselves in Musselburgh.Alistair and Colin had married local girls and Ian had taken up a post in youth and community education. He also later married a Musselburgh girl.All three had dabbled in folk music in the past and regularly went to the Golf Tavern in Millhill, Musselburgh, to hear local folk singers, the Amulree Trio, Chris Egan and his daughters, Lorraine and Karen.Alistair explained: "We each would sing a few songs inidually in the triorsquos break. One week John Gillan, the owner of the pub, askedwe could try and fill a night when the Amulrees were unavailable."We had a practice, everything just clicked and Yard Of Ale was born. We played every Friday and Saturday at the Golf for three years and took our name from the yard glass which hung on the wall. We were encouraged by local comedian, Billy Nimmo , to try our hand in the club cabaret scene."Yard Of Ale then had many successful years on the pub and club circuit, winning the TV Times Pub Entertainers of the Year award. The band did well on ITVs New Faces and appeared on many television and radio shows including STVrsquos Thingummyjig and BBC Radio Scotlandrsquos Scottish Radio Orchestra Roadshow. During this time they also supported, amongst others, Matt McGinn, Hamish Imlach and Billy Connolly, and enjoyed an extended run in the Edinburgh Festival with the legendary Tim Hardin.They then went their separate ways with Alistair involved in solo cabaret work, Colin playing with the North Sea Gas folk group and Iain, the original guitarist, leading a rock band.In  the group reformed for a charity show at the Brunton Theatre with good friends The Mimics, a successful Musselburgh comedy showband who had also broken up previously, to mark the passing of their mentor Billy Nimmo. The event was so successful that the band decided to give it another go.Since then its popularity has continued to grow and it has been in great demand for concerts, folk festivals, corporate s, pub, hotel and club gigs all over Scotland and when on tour in Denmark and in Ireland.Peter Gillan, nephew of the Golfrsquos John Gillan, then joined the band when Ian retired in . Having spent many years playing solo as a singer and guitarist on the folk and country scenes, his experience added yet another dimension to the band.Walter Mowat joined Yard Of Ale in  when Colin retired. Over the years he has played in a number of folk and bluegrass bands and also plays violin in the Really Terrible Orchestra.Ian and Colin still occasionally feature with the band as deputies or for larger concerts.Alistair and Ian each have two sons who were brought up and educated in Musselburgh.Alistairrsquos sons were both taught at the Burgh School by Susan Macintosh, Peterrsquos we.Peter started his working le at Bruntonrsquos Wiremill and still works for Brunton Aero products as it is now. He has also become a leading light in the Musselburgh Athletic FCrsquos  Club.Alistair was a director for  years of the now defunct Musselburgh Fair Day Association which ran the annual trotting at Musselburgh racecourse. He also ran a youth club for a number of years in Northesk Church and was chairman of the Musselburgh Domino League for a few years.In August,Yard of Ale played a fundraiser for Musselburgh Athletic Football Club to help them achieve their transition to senior football.The fundraising concert for the Hollies Day Centre has been organised by Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council. The sell-out event will take place on Friday at Loretto Church Hall.The Get Tom To Austin Fundraising Concert is planned for Saturday, November , at the Fisherrow Centre in South Street, Musselburgh. Mr Fairnie, , hoping to head to Texas next spring after being offered the chance to record an album of his own songs with the Grammy award winning producer Merel Bregante. formerly of the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band.

title: fundraiser-rhona-taylor-reaches-finish-line-for-alzheimers-research-uk
story: Rhona Taylor joined hundreds of people across the country in signing up for Alzheimerrsquos Research UKrsquos Running Down Dementia.The -year-old ran  kilometres to do her bit for the charity, which is close to her heart after her gran, Margaret Taylor, had dementia for about seven years.Rhona said: ldquoI think as well as getting the donations throughout, it really did spur me on knowing I was doing something in memory of my gran.ldquoSo many other people were doing the same challenge and being part of something bigger really helped.ldquoThere were a lot of days where I did not want to go out for a run, especially in the heatwave.ldquoIt was quite hard some days to keep going.According to Alzheimerrsquos Research UK, more than , people across the county have been diagnosed with dementia, with that figure expected to double within the next  years.University student Rhona previously told the Courier she was not a keen athlete but found she had come on leaps and bounds during the challenge, which she finished at the end of August.She said: ldquoI really improved.ldquoI think for the first month, the improvement was so slow and I was pretty worried but one of my last runs was an eight-kilometre run.ldquoI could only run about a tenth of that in the beginning.ldquoOnce I got over that hump, it was crazy ndash I was adding a kilometre every week to my personal best.ldquoFor me, time did not really matter.ldquoIt kind of came naturally and when I did shorter runs I was noticing I was getting a lot quicker but for me it was really about getting the distances since it seemed so unreachable for me in the beginning.Rhona got involved with Dementia Friendly Haddington when she was still at Knox Academy.She co-organised an event with fellow Knox pupil Kate Farmer at Haddington Day Centre, which saw an entire music class provide entertainment.Since then, she has done her bit for dementia and Alzheimer-related charities, raising pound through the challenge, and has not ruled out lacing up her running shoes again in the future after finding it not only improved her fitness but her mental health too.Speaking on Friday morning, the fourth year studying film at Edinburgh Napier University added: ldquoGenuinely, the reason I missed your call was I was about to go for a run.ldquoThat would be my first since I finished the challenge."I took a week off, I think I earned a week off but I am going to try to keep it up.ldquoI expected to get fitter but did not really expect how much of an impact it would have on my mood.ldquoJust genuinely you go for a run and there is no way you are going to feel bad afterwards.To support Rhona, go to run ningdowndementia.everydayhero uk rhona

title: public-get-their-say-on-proposed-community-shelter-in-north-berwick
story: That comes after North Berwick Youth Project ditched plans to revamp the shelter at the Gladsclune area of the town following complaints from local residents.Douglas Paul, chairman of Glasclune Residents Association, told the Courier earlier this summer that the proposals to redevelop the run-down shelter and turn it into a youth shelter were "second-rate."He added: "We feel that it is the wrong site for this.ldquoWe are open to the accusation that itrsquos because it is at the back of our house and thatrsquos partly fair ndash ideally wersquod like to see the shelter pulled down."Mr Paul, alongside half a dozen other local residents, attended a meeting of North Berwick Community Councillast week.Lauren Cowie, manager from North Berwick Youth Project, also attended, and revealed their initial plans for Glasclune have now been shelved."We do not want to fight against people for this," she told the NBCC meeting in the Hope Rooms.And she added: "We have listened to the feedback from local residents and we feel like we should look at alternative sites."Previously Mr Paul and his we Kathryn told the Courier they would be "delighted" to help the youth project with fundraising.And the re-iterated that stance at last weeks meeting.Mrs Paul said: "We have offered to fundraise with you and help manage the project and wed be delighted to do that."Ms Cowie thanked them for their offer.However, Mrs Paul also said the run-down shelter remained a problem."It is  feet from our bedroom window and recently theres been homeless people sleeping in it."It still needs sorted out."Mr and Mrs Paul have previously said theyd like the shelter knocked down.The public consultation into a future site for the community shelter will take place in the Hope Rooms next Wednesday from pm.All are welcome to attend.

title: former-x-factor-star-caitlyn-vanbeck-teams-up-with-radio-station-to-release-single
story: The former X-Factor star teamed up with Forth One to release the track, which is a remix of Marillions hit Kayleigh.The song was re-written by Breakfast Show host Andy Bouglas, known asBoogie, and remixed by producer Marty Ewart with help from fellow host Arlene Stuart and her son Robbie. The quartet combine to form BAMR, the name the song will be released under.Ahead of the singles release, Caitlyn washoping the single would break into the charts.She told the Courier: "Im absolutely over the moon. I think with this one wersquore looking to get it into the main charts, but Irsquod be happy with anything in the top ."Boogie said: ldquoWhat a journey this has been. Who knew a comment in January could lead to all this  This is what I love about our listeners ndash the fact that together, we can create something totally unique.ldquoThe original song lsquoKayleighrsquo never made it to number one, it peaked at number two, so we are really hoping that we can go one better and land the top spot with lsquoBreak Your Heartrsquo, that really would be a dream come true. So come on people of Edinburgh, the Lothians and Fe, we need your support to make history, and together we can do it!The chart show starts at pm, and at that time the track sat at Number  in the charts, ahead of global superstars such as Kanye West, Eminem and ArianaGrande.Break Your Heartis available on iTunes, Apple Music, Spoty, Amazon, Deezer and YouTube.You can watch the lyric video here . .To buy on iTunes,click here.To listen on Spoty, click here.

title: aberlady-set-to-turn-the-clock-back-with-historical-event
story: A heritage day ndash called Aberlady All Eras ndash takes place and explores the historical roots of the coastal village, with talks, workshops and a dinner party.The celebration, sponsored by Rettie  Co and Gullane Area Community Council, is held between am and pm.Ruthanne Baxter, one of the organisers, told the Courier: ldquoLast September, Aberlady Church was open for guided tours.ldquoThe people who went were very interested but there was very few of them.ldquoAfterwards, I said we would have had more people come to the churchthere was more going on [in the village].So we got in touch with the school and they were delighted to get involved in this project.ldquoBecause this is the Year of Young People, wersquove had a few young people involved too.ldquoWe also have two young people from the festival management degree at Queen Margaret University helping out. In total therersquos probably a core of eight people working on it.Ruthanne, a museums services manager at the University of Edinburgh, said they expected a turnout of up to  people.She added: ldquoIf it goes well we would most certainly do it again next year.Having gone to church in Aberlady for the past two years, Ruthanne explained where the idea came from.She said: ldquoIrsquom a heritage professional: I live, eat and breathe this kind of thing.ldquoIrsquom from a very rural part of Ireland. I love these rural heritage sites, so thatrsquos what motivated me and inspired me to do this.There will be a walking tour of the village as well as a guided tour of the church, which will be held on the hour and on the half hour from am with the last guided tour at .pm.The tours will be led by Ian Malcolm, of Aberlady Historical Society.There will be multiple talks throughout the day, held in room one at the primary school, hosted by Hugh Dan MacLennan, Dr Susan Buckham, Hamish Reid and Sarah Dunnigan, covering an array of topics from football to Sir Walter Scott.Meanwhile, drop-ins and workshops will be taking place in a second room at the school.From noon to .pm, there will be an example of school tests throughout the decades, followed at pm by an exploration of Robert Louis Stevenson stories.At .pm, there is a chance to design your familyrsquos coat of arms and, finally, at pm, Andy Heald will provide an overview of the Aberlady Angles project.There will also be wartime-era workshops running from noon to pm in the village hall.Kicking off with a military ancestry workshop, Gillian Chapman will present an exhibition on heavy horses before a swing dance session at pm.Finally at pm, young heritage costume company lsquoMesdame de lrsquohistoirersquo will pop in with a photobooth,you fancy seeing what you would have looked like in wartime garb.The Ducks Inn plays host to the eventrsquos evening dinner party at pm.John Paul McLachlan, the venuersquos head chef, joining forces with lsquoMesdame de lrsquohistoirersquo to create a magnicent meal from the Georgian era.Starting with lsquoRegency White Souprsquo, the main course is lsquoRoasted Whole Mini Chickens in Grulrsquo, followed by a dessert of lsquoWhim Whamrsquo, with Alastair Hardie playing fiddle and Eilidh Murray singing Burns songs.To book a table, call Ducks Inn on   and to book a place at any of the events email aberladyall eras@gmail

title: mairi-okeefe-to-retire-from-leuchie-house
story: Mrs OrsquoKeefe, , has led the charity, based on the outskirts of North Berwick, since  when it was operated by the MS Society, and subsequently since its formation as an independent charity from .In the past seven years, Mrs OrsquoKeefe and her team have been responsible for securing pound. million in grants from trust funds and donations from generous members of the public, as well as support from the Scottish Government.This has enabled the charity to deliver more than , respite nights since setting up as an independent charity.In , Leuchie House supported people with more than  dferent conditions to benefit from short breaks with -hour care.The North Berwick resident, who will be leaving in November, said: ldquoEveryone who knows me knows how passionate I am about Leuchie House and the very special service we provide.ldquoIt was always going to be dficult to step down, but I know I can do so feeling proud of everything wersquove achieved.ldquoIrsquove been honoured to experience on a daily basis just how much of a dference Leuchie makes to all the hundreds of families we support every year.ldquoI would like to say a huge thank you to my team ndash staff and volunteers ndash for all their support and commitment. I will miss them, our guests, and everyone  involved with Leuchie very much.Sir David Tweedie, chairman of Leuchie House Trustees, said: ldquoIn  when Leuchie House was faced with closure, Mairirsquos deep concern for those in need of respite and for their carers led her to launch the lsquoSave Leuchiersquo campaign.ldquoBy sheer force of personality she secured the support of Scottish and UK politicians, the media and the general public, generating sufficient backing to set Leuchie up as an independent charity.ldquoMairirsquos legacy is the happiness and relief she has brought to so many families by her dedication and compassion.ldquoThe board wishes her all the best in her well-deserved retirement and looks forward to working with our magnicent staff team as we look to the future.ldquoWe are delighted that Mairi has agreed to continue her connection with Leuchie by joining Gavin Hastings as a patron of Leuchie House.Mrs OrsquoKeefe will be replaced by Mark Bevan, most recently chief executive of the Scottish Council for Development and Industry..but resigned in August.And Mr Tweedie added: ldquoMark has held senior positions in both the care sector and in public policy and the board looks forward to working with him as we all seek to build on the great legacy left by Mairi.

title: tims-tales-silence-breeds-intolerance
story: Families of men, women and children were crammed into the insanitary cells. Reports that some of their friends had been seen near the town made the magistrates fear that they may try to help the prisoners escape.But what was troubling them more was the ldquoburdensome cost and inconvenience of incarcerating so many people. A decision on their fate was needed quickly.The town authorities had followed the law by putting them in prison. In fact, the law was clear that they should all be executed.But since there were women and children among them the Haddington authorities had hesitated to carry this out.They needed guidance and instruction from the Privy Council, and so a rider was dispatched with a letter asking for instructions, and the prisoners had to wait to hear of their fate. What had these people done to be under sentence of death It was nothing they had done. Their crime was who they were. They were gypsies just to be a gypsy was a capital offence.It was Arthur of Whittinghehame who had apprehended the families. The scene of this raid is not recorded.Was it a night raid, dragging women and children from their tents  Had they been families passing en route or camped nearby. Whole families were taken, but perhaps some escaped.Those who fled were perhaps the ones later seen near Haddington, worried and concerned about the fate of those imprisoned. No resistance seems to have been offered, forit had, the violence would have certainly been noted and used against them.They were accused of no crime other than that of being gypsies. It was a Privy Council edict in  which first declared the death penalty for being a gypsy in Scotland.It was written into statue by an act in .The Act called on all ldquogood subjects to apprehend gypsies and for the local authorities to imprison them and ldquoexecute to death the said Egyptians, either men or women. .And so these families were victims of a law that aimed to ethnically cleanse Scotland of gypsies. The Act was motivated by racist hatred and the only evidence needed to condemn someone to death was a Gypsy name, being known as a gypsy, or just associating with known gypsies.When the reply from the Privy Council arrived it was brutally clear in its instructions.It said there was a need to set an example to ldquothe rest of that infamous byke, thereby comparing gypsies to a nest of wasps or hornets.It continued: ldquoThe lords of secret counsel ordains the sherf of Haddington or his deputes to pronounce doom and sentence of death upon the men, and the women without children ldquothe men to be hangit and the women to be drowned.The women with children were to be spared death, but were to be ldquoscourgit threw the burgh of Haddington and burnt on the cheek.They would then be banished from Scotland. The Provost and bailies of Haddington were ordered to speedily carry out this sentence as stated. We can only assume these instructions were adhered to with little delay. If so, the executions will have been in public, and must have been a scene of horror, possibly witnessed by the friends and relatives.They were not the first gypsy families to suffer this persecution. In fact a number of gypsy families living in the Roslin area of Midlothian had previously been rounded up in . They had committed no crimes and kept a low profile. The Privy Council even complained that they were living ldquoasthey were lawful subjects. Their crime however, was to be ldquopart of an outlawed race and they were taken to Edinburghrsquos Tolbooth. The men were hanged and the women and children were banished from Scotland forever under pain of death.The aim of the persecution was to rid Scotland of Gypsies all together. So Gypsy families found themselves living like the wolf, hunted and in constant danger of capture. The Act of  was only part of it. An even earlier edict had empowered the masters of salt pans and coal mines to capture and enslave gypsies and other ldquovagabonds for servitude in the mines and salt pans.Many miners and salt panners at that time would have been enslaved gypsies. In many ways, their experience of state persecution and social discrimination mirrored that of the MacGregors, a Highland clan who were proscribed at much the same time.And like the MacGregors many gypsy families changed their names to avoid being identied.Others felt forced to changed their lestyle and hide their true identity, while some lived on the edge, with a constant risk of imprisonment or death. This was why there was a concentration of gypsy families close to the English border, as the laws were dferent in England.The attempt to exterminate gypsies from Scotland failed, they survived despite the persecution.But most of the misery and injustice caused remains unrecorded by history, although is not unforgotten by the gypsy community.In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries gypsies often shared the road with other travellers, many from the Highlands or Ireland, creating a gypsy traveller tradition with distinct cultural dferences between them, but a shared ldquonon-settled lestyle.But even when the laws were no longer enforced, the social attitudes towards gypsies and then also travellers excluded them.They were too dferent in the way they looked and dressed, and especially in the way they lived their lives. They had their own language and didnrsquot fit in. So I was told when I was wee.I grew up with derogatory comments in the playground about lsquoTinksrsquo and lsquoGyposrsquo. Such attitudes had been passed down by adults. Without knowing it I absorbed the idea that they were a people not to be trusted or liked. It was all self evident to me at the time because so many people were saying it.The truth is, of course, no community is all good or all bad, and choosing to select something bad to justy a blanket prejudice of a people is racism and intolerance of dference. I was angry later that I had been taught to demonise a people I knew nothing about. I discovered their history, not just their persecution, but their cultural and economic contribution to our country. Gypsies and travellers are rightly proud of their traditions, and I believe they are not ldquoother, but an important part of Scottish le and culture.It is sad that so many gypsy and traveller families, even today, hide their identity because of the discrimination they may face. And that discrimination still remains entrenched I think. I overheard a very loud ldquodiscussion about gypsies on a bus last week in which derogatory terms were used to describe them.It reminded me of things I was told when I was younger, and which I once believed to be true. It echoed the language used in the  Act and made my spine shiver.I didnrsquot challenge these comments, but I think I should have, constructively and politely. But to be honest I was afraid to.Irsquom ashamed about that ndash silence is the ground on which intolerance and hatred can grow.

title: bid-brewing-for-coffee-shop-and-drive-through-takeaway
story: The Motor Fuel Group has applied to East Lothian Council for planning consent for the outlet on land to the west of the existing Shell petrol filling station on Edinburgh Road. Tony Thomas, agent for the company, said: ldquoIt is an underused, scruffy site, frequently littered with uncollected dog mess.ldquoWe would like to use the site to introduce a modern, attractive drive-through takeaway coffee franchise with linked landscape and access proposals. This includes the creation of an attractive landscaped garden in the north east corner of the site looking to link the site to the historic Fisherrow Harbour.He added that the drive-through would offer people the chance to take away hot and cold drinks and hot and cold snacks, and there would be seating for customers in the coffee shop.A planning design and access statement, submitted on behalf of the company, stated: ldquoThe restaurant will be designed with on-site and drive-through facilities for vehicles, cycles and pedestrian access, with internal and external areas to enjoy refreshment for the passing traveller, as well as for the local community in the Fisherrow Harbour locality.Also planned is parking, new service lanes and a new landscape plan for the site.The statement added: ldquoIn terms of local economic benefit it is expected that the project will support a number of additional local part time jobs at the site when operational and there will also be additional employees on site during construction.ldquoThe proposed drive-through coffee shop is intended to supplement the existing petrol filling stationrsquosto serve the needs of passing motorists whilst providing useful services to the residential and commercial communities in and around Musselburgh, contributing positively to the sitersquos public realm offer.ldquoThe proposed development will create a place which is welcoming and distinctive by virtue of its design. It will be safe and pleasant ensuring ease of movement for vehicles and pedestrians to enter exit the site and move around the site in a clear and legible manner.ldquoDropped kerbs will allow safe movement of pedestrians between uses on-site, while road marking and signage within the site will indicate direction of travel and facilities. The site is adaptable in that it is linked to the wider area by road and footpath links, with parking provided to suit a range of users.ldquoThe drive-through facility will be accessed via a dedicated, signposted route which runs to the rear of the building and exits back onto the main exit route from the parking area. This enables customers to continue their journey or park up in the car park before exiting the site via normal channels.The coffee shop drive-through, which will have  parking bays including two for disabled motorists, will operate  days a year between am to pm.Five cycle stands will be provided which will be located to the front of the new building in association with the retained trees in that location. There would be earth embankment and tree planting carried out, with benches provided for public amenity.

title: tranent-mans-bid-for-world-peace-through-apple-trees
story: Alan Bell, of Muirpark, is leading the charge to plant more fruit trees in the town.He told the Courier: ldquoThe idea came from a few groups I speak with, who work outside this country, and they believe in world peace. Basically, the motto iswe can agree on one thing, it would be world peace ndash because who could disagree on that ldquoThey want people to plant trees and orchards, because what is better than free food that people can have whenever they want.The first trees are yet to be planted, but Alan has launched an appeal on Facebook asking people for their ideas about where to plant them.He said: ldquoWersquove got thousands of people interested worldwide, but even my post on Tranent Folks [a Facebook group] was popular. I think it got  replies in the first couple of hours, so that was quite encouraging. ldquoIt would be somewhere in public view, so you could prevent vandalisation or damage, but also out of the way of people so they wouldnrsquot be hit by falling fruit or slip on fallen fruit. People also suggested somewhere like a childrenrsquos schoolyard or area, which is good because teachers and janitors can see over them.Alan says he is delighted to have the support of East Lothian Council.He added: ldquoI thought why not ask the council about it and they were very enthusiastic and loved the idea.ldquoIt was a surprise, but I was delighted, obviously.Alan was further motivated after a tour round an orchard in Glasgow.The -year-old said: ldquoIt was a childrenrsquos orchard in the botanical gardens, and he allowed me to sponsor a tree there and get a plaque with my name on it.An East Lothian Council spokesperson told the Courier: ldquoA Tranent resident has approached the council with a proposal to plant apple trees in Tranent.ldquoNo sites have yet been identied and a member of the local amenity team will meet Mr Bell to discuss his idea more fully and to agree possible sites.Alan will now meet with Andrew Hogarth, an area amenity officer.

title: polish-show-strikes-gold-at-ceremony
story: Pol.ON ndash The Polish Show was named Community Show of the Year at the Community Radio Awards in Sheffield.The programme, presented by Marzena Farana-Sherlock, is broadcast each Monday, -pm, on Haddingtonrsquos East Coast FM.Mrs Farana-Sherlock, who started the show three-and-a-half years ago, was ldquospeechless after receiving the award.She said: ldquoFor me, it is a huge privilege to receive the award and I am delighted about it.ldquoIt shows how the work within community is interlinked.ldquoIt would not have happened without my passion for the radio, an idea for the Polish show, without East Coast FM agreeing to host the show and it would not have happened without the involvement of the Polish community.The show features a mix of music and interviews and is aimed at the Polish community throughout East Lothian and beyond.Mrs Farana-Sherlock, who has lived in Haddington for more than three years and been involved in radio for more than a decade, added: ldquoIt is a great way of promoting ersity and gives a chance to introduce Polish culture and also a fantastic opportunity for people who might struggle with the language barrier to become aware of what is happening in their local communities.ldquoThey are then aware of things that might affect their daily lives.Ian Robertson, founder and station manager, was similarly pleased with the success, which carried on a fine run of form at the annual awards ceremony.Mr Robertson said: ldquoI keep saying, we do not do it for the awards, they seem to come along.ldquoGetting the Community Show of the Year award for the second time ndash we got it  for the School Bell ndash is great.

title: support-the-armed-forces-at-musselburgh-raceday
story: The penultimate flat meeting of  welcomes back The Royal Regiment of Scotlandand Massed Bands consisting of The SCOTS Lowland Band,  SCOTS Pipes and Drums and the Royal Scots Association Pipe Band.With the regimental mascot, Shetland pony Cruachan IV, to the fore, the bands will start the raceday in style, parading on the racecoursersquos finishing straight and will play throughout the day at other locations.A range of interactive armed forces displays will be positioned around the racetrack grounds, with support from  Regiment Royal Artillery and a climbing wall and assault course will be staffed by members of the Lothian  Borders Air Cadet Force.Links between Scottish regiments and the Honest Toun go back more than  years. G Company th Volunteer Battalion The Royal Scots were based by Fisherrow Links in a drill hall which has since become a Baptist church, and on the formation of the Territorial Force the th Volunteer Battalion became the th Territorial Battalion.An Army spokesman said: ldquoIt is always a pleasure to be back at Musselburgh, carrying on a long military connection with the Honest Toun. The soldiers at Musselburgh Racecourse are represented by The Royal Regiment of Scotland and  Regiment Royal Artillery.Representatives from the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service will be on site along with officers from Police Scotland.Children aged  and under are admitted free to the raceday when accompanied by an adult and can enjoy an array of free activities including trampolines, fairground rides and face painting, a balloon artist and climbing wall.Younger children will be thrilled to find Casper the Unicorn will be a special guest and there will be an opportunity to have photographs taken with the rare breed Eriskay pony.Aisling Johnston, Musselburgh Racecourse marketing manager, said: ldquoThis is one of our biggest family racedays of the year and we hope everyone will come along to support our fantastic services who are ready to respond to our emergencies week in week out.ldquoThere is entertainment and fun activities for families of all ages, all set against a wonderful backdrop of colour and traditional music supplied by The SCOTS and the massed bands who are hugely popular at Musselburgh. We know young children will really enjoy meeting Casper the Unicorn and we are delighted he is making his first appearance at Musselburgh.The race programme features prize money of nearly pound, over seven races and the first race is off at .pm with gates open at noon.For more information and to book tickets please visit www.musselburgh-racecourse

title: making-a-tapestry-for-musselburgh
story: Stitchers are invited to attend another workshop at the Old Town Hall.It follows a successful bid to attract volunteers to join the community project which is expected to take two years to complete.Andrew Crummy, the artist behind the Great Tapestry of Scotland and Battle of Prestonpans Tapestry, spoke at a recent event in the Old Town Hall as did Melissa Viguier from the School of Ancient Crafts.The Battle of Pinkie Cleugh, which took place between Wallyford, Musselburgh and Dalkeith on September , , has been described as the largest and bloodiest conflict ever fought on Scottish soil.It began after the English king Henry VIIIrsquos attempts to secure an alliance with Scotland through the marriage of his young son Edward to the infant Mary, Queen of Scots, failed.Part of a conflict known as the Rough Wooing, it is considered to be the first modern battle in the British Isles and a catastrophic defeat for Scotland.Now the Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Group is working with Mr Crummy to make sure the last pitched battle between Scottish and English armies, in which , were killed, is not forgotten.The tapestry will be loosely based on the Marian Hangings stitched by Mary, Queen of Scots. Ms Viguier and a team of Edinburgh stitchers crafted a complete replica of the Marian hangings which can be seen at Edinburgh Castle.The Battle of Pinkie Cleugh tapestry will take the form of a series of embroideries hung on velvet which, it is hoped, will find a permanent home at The Brunton in Musselburgh.The Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Group has already secured pound, from the Musselburgh Common Good Fund, which will pay for the first phase of the tapestry. Chief stitcher Liz Neilson and her team will lead the work.Volunteer stitchers are welcome to attend future workshops at the Old Town Hall from am to pm on October  and , November  and December .Alister Hadden, treasurer of the Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Group, said: "We were delighted with how well attended the launch event was. It is really good to see so much work being done and we are sure the tapestry will be a huge success, and highlight this important battle."

title: north-berwick-resident-greatly-honoured-at-becoming-bha-chairman
story: Atholl Duncan will take over from incumbent Steve Harman when he steps down on November .The appointment of Mr Duncan, current senior independent director of the BHA board, was recommended by the BHArsquos nominations committee, which features representatives of the BHArsquos members ndash the Racecourse Association , the Racehorse Owners Association, licensed personnel and the Thoroughbred Breedersrsquo Association.Mr Duncan, who lives near Abbotsford Road, said of his new role: ldquoIt is a great honour for me to be appointed as chairman of the BHA.ldquoMy immediate focus will be to continue to work closely with everyone across horseracing to shape the right improvements we need to meet the many challenges facing our sport.ldquoI also look forward to supporting and constructively challenging the BHA executive and the highly dedicated teams across the country who we rely on every day to ensure the smooth running, integrity and welfare of racing.An experienced non-executive director in sports organisations, Atholl was a senior executive at the BBC for many years.He spent four years as director of corporate affairs with Scottish Water and since  was executive director of ICAS, the professional body of chartered accountants, before joining the BHA board in .Atholl was also a non-executive director of Sportscotland for nine years and sat on the Scottish Sports Council Trust and the Hibernian Football Club Community Foundation.He has been a regular racegoer for nearly  years is a Trustee of the Caledonian Racing Society has been an owner in several syndicates and has horses in training with Lucinda Russell.The appointment is on an ongoing basis with no fixed term while the BHA and its members continue constructive discussion regarding the make-up of the BHA board and the remit of the chairman.

title: energy-efficient-homes-are-a-real-boost-for-new-tenants
story: The pound million Dunedin Canmore development at Affleck Rise, opposite Farsquoside Avenue South, is a mix of one and two-bed cottage flats and two and three-bed houses, which are all for social rent. Solar  have been fitted to generate electricity, helping cut tenantsrsquo fuel bills.The new development, part-funded by a pound.m grant from the Scottish Government, is part of a project to build , new homes, a new primary and secondary school, open spaces and sports facilities in Wallyford.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos housing spokesman, said: ldquoMeeting tenants and seeing how happy and settled they already are in their fantastic new homes was a real privilege.ldquoOf course, ensuring that our residents have access to high-quality social housing is a key aim for East Lothian Council and itrsquos essential that we work with organisations like Dunedin Canmore to deliver this.ldquoBut it also goes wider than that and this regeneration of Wallyford is all about building strong communities.ldquoTo that end, the council has been invested in ensuring that all of our new tenants will have great access to shops, facilities and new schools.ldquoIndeed, construction of the new primary school on this site is already well advanced.ldquoEast Lothian is a popular place to live and, as a council, we are continually working to make sure we develop and enrich strong and vibrant communities.ldquoIrsquom sure our new tenants here in Wallyford will very much enjoy their new homes and the community that surrounds them.Mr Goodfellow was joined at the official opening by some of the new residents, staff from Dunedin Canmore and its parent company Wheatley Group, local elected members and representatives from Scottish Government, East Lothian Council and contractor Hart Builders, part of the Cruden Group.Tenant Angela Coyle moved into her new house with her young family at the end of March.She said: ldquoWe had lived in Wallyford for years but got moved to temporary accommodation in Tranent last year when our landlord sold our home.ldquoWe really wanted to come back as we love the area.ldquoTherersquos a community feel to the place and everybody is getting on. My son Liam is always out on his bike with the other children on our street.Mary Mulligan, chairwoman of Dunedin Canmore, said: ldquoOur plans were shaped by what tenants in the area told us they needed and wersquore particularly pleased we were able to deliver private gardens for every flat as well as the energy efficient features like solar .Housing Minister Kevin Stewart said: ldquoThis is a very exciting project for Wallyford and Irsquom pleased that the Scottish Government has been able to co-fund the project with pound. million investment, giving more people access to high quality social rented housing with this  unit development also including nine amenity homes.

title: pedal-power-proves-a-real-boost-to-surfing-group
story: Ebon and Ansel Parkin decided to take on a challenge, which would see them cycle from Clydebank, west of Glasgow, across the country and back to their home in Dunbar.The -mile trek, where they were joined by dad Dan, with family friend Davy Scott also lending a hand, saw the two brothers setting off at about .am.Dad Dan was impressed by their efforts, which saw them raise more than pound for The Wave Project, as they pedalled along cycle paths, canal paths and roads.He said: ldquoI certainly am proud. A lot of people have said lsquowow,  milesrsquo. If you do a lot of cycling maybe that does not seem that far but for little, short legs like Ansel, his bike is tiny and he cycled further than we did technically.The quartet set off from near the Erskine Bridge before heading east to Lenzie and on towards West Lothian.They then followed the Union Canal into Edinburgh and then onto to East Lothian, following the coast through Musselburgh and North Berwick.Finally, the tired cyclists reached their destination on Dunbarrsquos Retreat Gardens after eight hours and nine minutes in the saddle.Dunbar Grammar School pupil Ebon said: ldquoI didnrsquot want to be glued to the telly and I wanted something challenging to work hard on. Riding  miles sounded like a great idea.The idea came about at Christmas when the family were discussing potential new yearrsquos resolutions.Nine-year-old Ansel, who attends Dunbar Primary School, and big brother Ebon, , are keen surfers and had already agreed to take on the challenge before deciding to do their bit for The Wave Project.Ansel said: ldquoI wanted to set myself a challenge for this year. I thought about what I liked best. I love cycling. So, I set a target of riding  miles.The charity, which brings people together through surfing, is based at Belhaven Bay.It aims to increase youngstersrsquo confidence and feel less anxious through surfing sessions.Alison Young, coordinator of The Wave Project, thanked the duo for their help. She said: ldquoThank you so much boys, look forward to seeing you in the surf soon!

title: giant-sponge-of-mosses-tackling-air-pollution-in-musselburgh
story: Air pollution in the centre of the Honest Toun has long been a cause for concern.Now, a giant sponge of mosses has been put in place on High Street, outside the police station, in the hope of cutting nearby pollution by close to a third.CityTree has been developed by German green technology firm Green City Solutions who say the combination of mosses in the structure can filter air pollutants - including nitrogen dioxide - from the surrounding air by up to  per cent.Derek Oliver of East Lothian Council described the structure as a "innovative approach"to tackling air quality issues.He added: "It is anticipated to raise awareness and influence behavioural change around pollution and climate change. We will seek public opinion following the pilot period.The East Lothian CityTree has been funded by the Scottish Government through the East Central Scotland Vehicle Emissions Partnership and has been installed in the designated Air Quality Management Area of Musselburgh High Street for an initial four-month pilot period.Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet member for environment, added: ldquoIt is particularly appropriate that we are installing this CityTree at the start of Climate Week Scotland  and it will be interesting to see what impact it will have on air pollution in Musselburgh High Street."A number of measures have been outlined in the Musselburgh Air Quality Action Plan to tackle poor air quality including introducing new technology, aiming to reduce vehicle emissions, and encouraging sustainable travel options."Whether as an inidual, business or school, we can all play a part in taking action to improve our environment and I hope the CityTree will act as a focus for future ideas.The installation powers itself via solar , and rainwater is collected and automatically redistributed using a built-in irrigation system. This provides ideal conditions for the mosses to grow in an urban environment.East Lothian is the second local authority in Scotland to have a CityTree, following Glasgow City Council.CityTree technology has also been installed in Berlin, Paris, Brussels, Hong Kong, Amsterdam, Oslo, London and Newcastle.

title: dave-whelan-caught-offside-in-powerleague-restructuring-plan
story: The Press Association can reveal that the owner of Wigan Athletic also owns three of the sites that are either earmarked for closure or will have their rental terms changed as part of Powerleaguersquos Company Voluntary Arrangement .Powerleague announced earlier this week that it is to axe more than  jobs as it presses ahead with the closure programme.The group, owned by Patron Capital Partners, will shut  of it  sites through the CVA, a controversial insolvency procedure used by struggling firms to close under-performing units.It will also seek rent reductions or dferent rental terms on the remaining estate and landlords such as Mr Whelan take a financial hit as a result.A spokeswoman for the sports retail tycoon, who also used to own JJB Sports, told PA: ldquoAs landlord toPowerleagueacross three sites in the UK we will be working with them in line with the statutory CVA process to come to an agreement on next steps for all parties.ldquoAt this moment we are not in a position to comment any further until these discussions have moved forward.It is unclear whether Mr Whelanrsquos sites are among those set to close or ones that will see rent terms changed.Powerleague said the CVA is a ldquolast resort, adding that it will go bust without the restructuring.Deloitte is handling the CVA, which will require the backing of % of creditors, including landlords such as Mr Whelan.Mr Whelan is in the process of selling his familyrsquos majority holding in Wigan Athletic toHong Kong-based International Entertainment Corporation.His business interests also span gyms through DW fitness First and he also owns the DW Stadium, where Wigan play.

title: staying-in-customs-union-after-2020-would-be-utter-disgrace-says-rees-mogg
story: Mr Rees-Mogg was responding to unconfirmed reports in The Times suggesting Prime Minister Theresa May is preparing to limit Britainrsquos ability to strike free-trade deals after Brexit in a bid to break deadlock in negotiations.The chairman of the European Research Groupof Eurosceptic Tories said any extension of the customs union beyond the end of the -month transition period following Brexit would be ldquothe most serious breach of trust between the Government and the governed I can imagine.At #CPC @Jacob_Rees_Mogg tells the European Research Group that #Chequers offers "worse servitude, worse vassalage than we we have already got" #Brexit pic KwFYgbXcPtmdash Andrew WoodcockOctober , Speaking to a meeting of the ERG on the fringe of the Conservative conference in Birmingham, Mr Rees-Mogg claimed some Cabinet ministers had ldquovery much left the door open for the ldquosuper-Canada option preferred by himself and Boris Johnson.He even claimed Chancellor Philip Hammond was not ruling out a Canadian-style free trade deal, despite also warning: ldquoThere are some forces within the state that are desperate to stopand they seem to be centred around  Downing Street.Mr Rees-Mogg warned that a ldquoBrexit in name only ndash known to Brexiteers as Brino ndash would hand power to Jeremy Corbynrsquos Labour.If the Times story was right, ldquothat is not Brexit, that is Remain and it is an utter disgrace, he said.ldquoNot only would it be a disgrace in terms of whatI as a Leaver believe, it would be dishonourable in terms of what was promised to the British electorate. It would mean the manesto I stood for Parliament on was not meant.If the customs union was extended in this way ldquoit would open the door to  Downing Street for one Jeremy Corbyn hellip because Conservative voters would simply not turn out to vote, he warned.ldquoSeventy per cent of Tory voters are committed to Brexit. They will feel deeply let downBrexit is not delivered orit is Brino ndash Brexit in name only.ldquoThose of us who get accused of standing too firm for Brexit and therefore making it easier for Jeremy Corbyn are not the ones who ought to be criticised, because what we are doing by keeping faith with the British electorate is ensuring the Conservatives can be in a position to win the next election.Mr Rees-Mogg said opponents of Mrs Mayrsquos Chequers plan can vote it down in Parliament without fear of triggering a general election which Labour might win, because fixed-term legislation meant it could not be treated as a confidence vote.The Fixed-Term Parliaments Act ldquomeans people like me can vote against Chequers with a clear conscience, he said.Mr Rees-Mogg insisted he continues to support Mrs May as leader, although he criticised her for saying that Leave backers had ldquovoted with their hearts in . ldquoI donrsquot know about you, but I voted with my head as well, he said.He made clear he would favour tax cuts following Brexit, saying he wanted the UK to become not ldquoa tax haven but a tax heaven.He said Brexit would not stop him drinking French wine, winning laughs as he recalled how his son had asked him: ldquoDaddy,we leave the EU where will you get your claret from The meeting was held in a hotel outside the conference secure zone and did not feature in the official programme of events. Mr Rees-Mogg said the ERGrsquos room booking inside the conference centre was ldquomysteriously cancelled when it became clear who it was for.

title: glasgow-leads-the-uk-in-tackling-rough-sleeping
story: The cityrsquos homelessness services will be transformed over the next decade through the initiative.Glasgowrsquos Health and Social Care Partnershipwill recruit partners to form the Alliance to tackle rough sleeping, prevent homelessness and alleviate its impact, reduce theof time people spend in temporary accommodation, minimise repeated homelessness and increase tenancy sustainment for people who were formerly homeless.In turn, it is hoped there will be a reduced dependency on temporary, stop-gap accommodation.The Alliance, which will include people with first-hand experience of homelessness, will be responsible for budget management and allocations for purchased homelessness services from the start of the contract in .Service providers will be invited to submit group bids to join the Alliance at the end of the year.Although the GCHSCP currently buys a number of homelessness services from Third Sector partners, the new Alliance will create a closer collaborative working.Councillor Mhairi Hunter, Chair of the Partnershiprsquos Integration Joint Board, said: ldquoThis is a really innovative and exciting development. We are taking a leap into uncharted territory here, but we need to develop new approaches to tackle this complex social issue.ldquoThere is nothing of this type in the UK. Glasgow will be leading the way by formalising arrangements with partners to make best use of the resources available.ldquoIt will be genuine partnership and ground-breaking stuff. We look forward to working collaboratively with partners to develop this ambitious new venture.A spokesman for Glasgow City Mission, said: ldquoWe are looking forward to the Glasgow Alliance to End Homelessness and is a strong supporter of this collaborative model.ldquoWhile any pioneering model leads to a level of uncertainty there is a strong positive sense of anticipation around the model and wersquod certainly be keen to play a role in it."Wersquore excited about the role of people with lived experience of homelessness shaping services. Wersquore also thrilled to be able to witness a sector move away from a competitive tendering process to a collaborative approach.The move comes after Glasgow City Council was strongly criticised for leaving people in temporary accommodation for too long.The Scottish Housing Regulator found people were spending an average of  days in temporary accommodation before they were found a home.Following the findings, the council agreed a plan with the regulator to speed up applications and assessments to get people through the process more rapidly.

title: dominic-raab-sends-brussels-strongest-signal-yet-uk-prepared-to-walk-from-brexit-talks
story: The Brexit Secretaryrsquos shot across the EUrsquos bows comes less than a week after Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn warned a no-deal Brexit would be a "national disaster".But with less than three weeks to go to the crunch October European Council, Mr Raab will use his keynote speech to the Conservative conference in Birmingham to rule out any deal which "locks in" Britain to the EU by membership of a customs union or the European Economic Area.He will also reject the European Commissions proposal for a "backstop" solution to the Irish border issue under which Northern Ireland would remain part of the EU customs area.The Secretary of State will say: "We are leaving the European Union in fact not just in name. If we cant obtain a deal that secures that objective... an attempt is made to lock us in via the back door of the EEA and customs union...orthe only offer from the EU threatens the integrity of our Union, then we will be left with no choice but to leave without a deal."Restating his backing for Mrs Mays Chequers Plan, Mr Raab will say: "My approach to Brexit is pragmatic, not dogmatic. Our proposals would deliver a historic agreement that provides a roadmap out of the EU and a final deal that will be good for the whole country."A deal that delivers on the referendum, because thats our democratic dutyhellipthat manages the risks of Brexit, because thats our responsibilityhellipthat grasps the opportunities of Brexit, because were at our best when were optimistic about the future."And a deal that protects our precious Union, because we are the Conservative and Unionist Party," he will declare.Mr Raabrsquos words follow remarks from Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary, who hit out at the EU for "taunting" the UK since its rejection of the Chequers Plan at the Salzburg summit.The first day of conference was dominated by the partyrsquos Brexit psychodrama with Theresa May and her colleagues defending her compromise proposals against Boris Johnsonrsquos attack in which he branded them ldquoderanged.The Prime Minister insisted her beleaguered Chequers Plan was not dead as she refused to rule out making any more compromises to secure a deal.She sought to reject Mr Johnsonrsquos suggestion that, as a true believer in Brexit, his ldquosuper-Canada trade deal plan was better placed to succeed than her blueprint, by declaring: ldquoI believe in Brexit.Mrs May also did not deny that a no-deal scenario would create a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, simply stating repeatedly that the UK Government was "committed" to ensuring that a hard border would not happen.Ruth Davidson came to the PMrsquos defence, suggesting Mr Johnsonrsquos harsh putdown of her Brexit compromise was ldquonot wise and called for Tory colleagues to observe a ldquoperiod of silence to give Mrs May the space to secure a deal.Today in her address to conference, the Scottish Conservative leader will strike out again at the former Foreign Secretary and his fellow Brexiteers by extolling the Conservative virtues of pragmatism and practicality and decrying the ldquoivory-towered schemes of the ideological puritan.She will tell conference: ldquoHerersquos the truth: we can agree a Brexit deal under the Conservatives or we can risk handing the keys of Downing Street to Jeremy Corbyn. I know which one I believe is in the national interest. I stand by the Prime Minister.Last night, Mrs May failed to turn up at the Scottish Conservative reception or indeed any other reception in a bid, said party sources, to "save her voice" and avoid a repeat of last yearrsquos embarrassing episode when she lost it repeatedly during her end-of-conference speech. Philip Hammond, the Chancellor, filled in for the PM at the Scots event.Earlier, the PM unveiled a plan for a Festival of Brexit Britain to celebrate our ldquoprecious Union planned for .And she announced plans to charge foreign home buyers in England up to a three per cent higher rate of stamp duty to stop them driving up prices in the UK with the revenue used use to tackle homelessness. Murdo Fraser for the Scottish Conservatives said the party would need to see how the plan translated into the Scottish system but said: ldquoIn principle, we would be supportive of this."

title: catherine-stihler-voters-have-right-to-change-minds-over-brexit
story: The alarm is set to chime next March and we still have no deal. It is worth remembering the leader of my party, Jeremy Corbyn, wanted to trigger Article  the day after the EU referendum ndash a reckless move that thankfully did not come to pass.Read more:Scots battle to win MPs right to halt Brexit likely to succeedAs many predicted, the Brexit process is in a mess, with the lies of the Leave campaign now fully exposed, and the harsh reality ofa hard Brexit now abundantly clear. It is not inevitable we leave the EU next March. Voters have the right to change their minds. I believe the UK has the right to change its mind and thatrsquos why I am proud to be involved in the cross-party legal fight, seeking a ruling from Europersquos highest court on whether Article  can be revokedMPs vote to do so. Following the Labour Party conference, with shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer putting the option of remaining back on the table, I believe we can build a majority in the UK Parliament to reverse Brexit.If we go ahead with leaving the EU, it will be the poorest in society who will suffer. For the sake of the workers of this country, and generations to come, I am not prepared to sit back and accept that Brexit is inevitable.

title: chris-grayling-announces-one-click-compensation-system-for-passengers-seeking-redress-for-delays
story: The Transport Secretary, who arrived on stage at the Tory conference seven minutes behind schedule, said changes would be implemented to make it easier for people to claim.Passengers, he explained, once registered on the new system, would not have to repeatedly enter their details every time they wanted to make a claim.New operators would also be expected to make greater use of technology, such as mobile phone apps, to inform passengers when they were entitled to compensation.Labour described the announcement as a "cheap gimmick" and argued it did not tackle the "underlying problems" that led to delays.In his conference address, Mr Grayling reiterated his apology for the chaos caused by timetable reforms this summer.After noting the number of passengers travelling on the railways had doubled in the last  years, he said: "Trains are packed, the network is creaking, passengers experience too many things going wrong."We need to look after them when that happens, which is why today I can announce that we will introduce one-click compensation for delays and disruption, making it easier for people to claim compensation."The Secretary of State defended the UK Governments spending record on railways and criticised Labour for a lack of investment when in power.But his Labour Shadow Andy McDonald hit back, saying: "After eight years of failure on transport, the time for tinkering at the edges is over."Rail is in chaos and the Tories one-click compensation plans are yet another cheap gimmick which do nothing to tackle the underlying problems causing misery to passengers across the country."Congestion on major roads has worsened, local roads have fallen into disrepair, the UK is failing on air pollution and we are set to miss the Paris climate change targets."

title: alyn-smith-article-50-was-never-designed-to-be-used
story: It is legitimate to want to leave the EU,but there was no prospectus, no unied proposition that people voted for so I believe it is a very flawed mandate.
